MainHeading.Title: Death of Member: Expression of Sympathy.

Speaker.P: Senators will have learned with deep regret of the death this morning of our colleague Senator James Dunne.

Born in Dublin some 50 years ago, he started work at an early age. Although he received little formal schooling he was an omnivorous reader and later attended University College, Dublin, where he was awarded an honours diploma in social and economic studies. A trade union official for some years, he became general secretary of the Marine Port and General Workers Union in 1957. He was for a period President of the Irish Congress of Trade Unions.
At the general election in 1969 he was elected to the Labour Panel of the Seanad on the nomination of the Congress.

Senator Dunne was of a kindly and friendly disposition in his personal relations, and his personality endeared him to all with whom he came in contact. His contributions both in the Seanad and outside were outstanding for their sincerity and courage. In Senator Dunne we have lost a colleague whose gifts of intelligence and humanity were widely appreciated. His untimely death will be keenly felt by all Members.
To the widow and children of the late Senator I shall convey, on your behalf and on my own, our deepest sympathy. Solas Dé lena anam.

MainHeading.Title: Private Business. - Solicitors' Remuneration General Order, 1971: Motion.

Speaker.hpid: Tomás Ó Maoláin Tomás Ó Maoláin
Speaker.P: I move:

MainHeading.P: That Seanad Éireann is of opinion that the Solicitors' Remuneration General Order, 1971, should be disallowed and requests the Government to disallow it.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.P: At the outset, I would like to explain briefly the manner in which solicitors' remuneration is fixed. With a view to the protection of clients, the rights of solicitors in regard to the amount and recovery of their costs are, unlike any other profession, almost entirely controlled by statute and orders made thereunder and by rules made by the various rule-making authorities set up by statute. Costs which a solicitor may charge in civil matters may be considered under the two broad divisions of legal work which a solicitor is called upon to perform for his client, namely, “contentious” and “non-contentious” business. Contentious business embraces the work executed by a solicitor for his client in connection with court proceedings of a civil nature. Non-contentious business, on the other hand, may be said to be that performed by a solicitor on behalf of his client in connection with legal transactions as distinct from court proceedings, for example, making a will, drawing a deed, selling, purchasing, leasing or mortgaging property, administering estates or trusts, and so on.

Costs in respect of all contentious business, non-contentious probate and administration, and registered conveyancing are regulated by rules made by the three rule-making authorities for the various courts and by the Registration of Title Rules Committee. Before coming into effect, such rules must have received the concurrence of the Minister for Justice.

MainHeading.P: Costs in respect of non-contentious business, other than non-contentious probate and administration and registered conveyancing, are regulated, on the other hand, by orders made under the Solicitors Remuneration Act, 1881, by the Statutory Body established thereunder. The Statutory Body consists of the Chief Justice, the President of the High Court, the senior ordinary judge of the Supreme Court and the President of the Incorporated Law Society of Ireland. An order made by the Statutory Body does not take effect unless and until it has been laid before each House of the Oireachtas and one month thereafter or four sitting weeks—that is, four weeks on which the House has sat—thereafter, whichever is the longer, have elapsed. However, the order may be disallowed, in whole or in part, by the Government on a resolution passed by either House within the relevant period seeking disallowance. It will be seen, therefore, that Parliament did not hand over to the Statutory Body the right to regulate costs, but reserved to itself the final say in the matter.

Under the Solicitors Remuneration Act, 1881, solicitors' remuneration has been regulated by order since 1884. The work covered has been divided into two categories and the remuneration for these was fixed under Schedules I and II, respectively, to the order of 1884. Schedule I provided scales of fees based on the amount of the consideration for sales, purchases, mortgages, leases, agreements for leases, and similar transactions. Schedule II covered other business of a non-contentious kind and continued the system then in force of charging for the work done by reference to a priced list of items. The order has been amended from time to time and charges provided for therein have been increased. The new order provides for an increase of 42 per cent in the Schedule II costs, that is, costs in non-contentious business—other than scale fees for sales, purchases, mortgages and so on—which costs were fixed at their present level in the Solicitors' Remuneration General Order, 1964.

The Solicitors' Remuneration General Order, 1971, cannot be considered in isolation but must be viewed as part of a general claim being pursued at present by the Incorporated Law Society for considerable increases in costs, both in contentious and non-contentious business. I have already refused to give my concurrence to new rules made by the Superior Court Rules Committee which provide for an increase of 42 per cent in solicitors' costs within the jurisdiction of that committee. Other rule-making authorities have also submitted for my concurrence new rules providing for very substantial increases in solicitors' costs within the jurisdiction of each committee. These rules are at present being examined.

The Government are satisfied that there is no justification for an increase in solicitors' costs of the magnitude proposed by the Statutory Body. It must be remembered that, since costs were fixed at their present level, solicitors' incomes have been substantially increased by higher amounts allowable under the head of “instructions”— which is a fee at large. These fees increase with the fall in money values and also with increases in the cost of running a solicitor's business. Moreover, the main item in a solicitor's bill of costs, whether for contentious or non-contentious business, is the “instructions” fee—a fee which in the case of Schedule II costs must be determined having regard to every relevant, and indeed conceivable, circumstance.

Increases in property values also bring in substantial increased remuneration since conveyancing costs are regulated on an ad valorem basis. Solicitors' costs for property transactions are much in excess of what could by any standard be considered reasonable. Solicitors in the State do better than solicitors in Northern Ireland and far better than solicitors in England and Scotland. This is all the more remarkable since conveyancing charges in England are constantly being criticised as being too high. The National Board for Prices and Incomes have recommended changes in conveyancing costs in England and Wales with a view to reducing solicitors' total income from conveyancing. The Lord Chancellor has recently put to the English Law Society certain proposals for changes in the bases of solicitors' remuneration for conveyancing work with a view to a reduction in conveyancing costs.

It used to be said that it was of the nature of a solicitor's business that while some parts of his business, e.g., District Court work, were not really remunerative this was offset by those parts of his business—for example, conveyancing and probate work—that were highly remunerative. The Government are satisfied that we have now reached the stage in this country where most parts of a solicitor's business can be said to be reasonably remunerative and that a very substantial part of his business is highly remunerative—and indeed, as I have already said, much more remunerative than in England, Scotland or the North of Ireland. In addition, the effect of the ad valorem scales for conveyancing is to link conveyancing charges with rises in property values, which generally rise faster than prices and costs. Between 1960 and 1970 the rate of increase in house prices in the Dublin area was double that in the cost of living. This link, coupled with a growing volume of business, has, in the view of the Government, enabled solicitors to keep up with rising costs.

I do not want it to be thought that the Government are totally opposed to any increase in solicitors' remuneration at the present time. They are prepared to accept that a reasonable increase would be justified, but certainly not an increase of the magnitude provided for in Solicitors' Remuneration General Order, 1971. However, as the law stands, the Oireachtas is not able to amend an order made by the Statutory Body. The order may be allowed to stand or disallowed in whole or in part. If the order is disallowed, the existing Schedule II costs will continue to operate and it will be open to the Statutory Body to make another order containing proposals of a more reasonable nature which may be acceptable. I have already indicated to both the Statutory Body and the Superior Courts Rules Committee that I am agreeable to a reasonable increase in the charges for both contentious and non-contentious business. I know that it is often argued that the solicitors' profession is unique in that it is the only profession whose remuneration is and has been over the years controlled by statutory powers vested in a Minister of State or in Parliament. However, as Senators will be aware, there is now before the Dáil a new and comprehensive Prices (Amendment) Bill that proposes to extend price control to all professional services.

The services with which I, as Minister for Justice, am particularly concerned are those rendered by lawyers and auctioneers. If the Prices Bill becomes law, the Government may by order transfer to me the powers and functions of the Minister for Industry and Commerce under the Prices Acts in relation to the fees of lawyers and auctioneers. If and when this is done, I will be able to establish an advisory body or bodies to inquire into the fees of the professions concerned and to make recommendations to me. The representatives of each profession may make their cases to those bodies, who will, I am sure, examine the various fees chargeable in the different areas of a solicitors' or auctioneer's business.

The trouble at the moment is that there are too many bodies dealing with solicitors' costs with the result that there is no overall assessment or examination of legal remuneration as a whole. This has led to a number of anomalies, the most glaring of which is that charges for registered conveyancing are in some cases higher than in unregistered conveyancing. This is unique in these islands, and is indefensible when one has regard to the fact that a registration of title system is supposed to reduce costs.

Indeed, in Scotland, where solicitors' conveyancing costs are substantially lower than ours, a Government Committee, under the chairmanship of Lord Reid, a Lord of Appeal in Ordinary, recommended in 1963 the introduction in Scotland of registration of title to land. They stated that on the whole they thought “that a reduction of 25 per cent on the present scale of fees should be achieved in transactions in land the title to which has been registered”.

The Government do not accept that, if the remuneration of a particular profession is controlled, the independence of that profession is put at risk. After all, the remuneration of judges and of the legal profession has historically been subject to Parliamentary and Government or Ministerial control both in Britain and in Ireland. Here, no rules of the Superior Courts or of the Lower Courts or of the Registration of Title Rules Committee may come into operation without the concurrence of the Minister for Justice—and concurrence has been refused from time to time by different Ministers in different Governments. In England, the Lord Chancellor, who is a senior Cabinet Minister, is a member of the Statutory Body as well as being a member of the Supreme Court Rule Committee. Moreover, rules made by the County Court Rule Committee in England may be allowed, disallowed or altered by the Lord Chancellor, whose Department is, inter alia, particularly concerned with legal remuneration.

By the way, I think I should mention that, under our Prices Acts, any Prices Order made by a Minister must be laid before each House of the Oireachtas, and it is subject to annulment by resolution passed by either House within 21 sitting days. The proposed new Prices Bill extends this control to professional remuneration. Also, the Bill contains in section 2 a provision which is designed to ensure that any power, arising under any other enactment to control, regulate or specify charges for professional or other services, shall not be exercised without the consent of the Minister concerned.

The making of a Remuneration Order under the Solicitors Remuneration Act, 1881, is not a judicial function. It is a case in which legislative powers have been delegated by Parliament to a statutory committee consisting of three judges and the President of the Law Society. In giving these powers, Parliament retained the authority to set aside any order made by the Statutory Body that it considered not to be in the public interest. The duty of the Oireachtas in this matter, therefore, is to safeguard that interest.

I regret that I have to request the House to exercise its control over the Statutory Body. However, the Government, having carefully considered all aspects of this matter, are fully satisfied that they would be lacking in their duty if they did not seek to have this order disallowed. The plain fact is that 42 per cent is by any reasonable standard far too much of an increase on present remuneration. One must bear in mind also the feelings of other sectors of the community of an increase of this kind is allowed. This is all the more so when one takes into account—as one must—that the “instructions” fee—which is a fee at large and the main fee in a solicitor's bill of costs—increases with the fall in money values and with the rise in the cost of running a solicitor's business, and that solicitors are doing exceptionally well from the fixed ad valorem charges, the highest in these islands, for the transfer of land and houses, whether registered or unregistered.

Speaker.P: On a point of order, I am not absolutely clear about the position of the motion that I raised, Sir. Could you clarify it? You accepted the motion but it was not put.
The motion was agreed to.

I ask this House to reject this motion. First of all, as a practising solicitor, I must declare an interest and I hope the arguments which I will place before the House will show that this motion should be rejected by the House on the merits of the case. I certainly do not want to appear to be in the position of arguing a case on the grounds of self interest. I do not think it is necessary. This motion should be rejected by this House because there is no reasonable justification for it. The Minister has mentioned correctly that up to now, in any event, the solicitors' profession is the only one which has been subject to control so far as costs and fees are concerned. It might interest the House to know that for a very considerable period, more than 100 years anyhow, the solicitors profession has been subject to such control. There have been a variety of Acts dealing with the question of solicitors' remuneration, starting at the Attorneys and Solicitors (Ireland) Act, 1849. There was then the Attorneys and Solicitors Act, 1870, the Legal Practitioners (Ireland) Act, 1876, Mortgagees Legal Costs Act, 1895, and the Solicitors Remuneration Act, 1881, and the general orders made under that Act with which the House is concerned today.

MainHeading.P: I wish to put it bluntly to the House that, regardless of whether the legal profession as such is popular or unpopular with the general public, that is not a matter that should be taken into account by the Minister or by any Member of this House. The solcitors' profession is as much entitled to fair play and fair remuneration as any other section of the community. Solicitors in common with other sections of the community are affected by increased prices. They are also affected by increased taxation increased rates and increased wages. But, unlike many other sections of the community, particularly the business sections, solicitors are subject to a rigid code of conduct and discipline which precludes anything in the nature of advertising or touting for business. The solicitor must rely on the reputation which he has established for himself, on his expertise, his efficiency and ability and general performance to attract new business and to increase output in his office. If costs are increased against the solicitor he has no way of offsetting that because he is rigidly controlled so far as his fees and costs are concerned. He cannot pass that on to the consumer. This would apply particularly to the younger solicitor and the smaller office. If there is not a compensatory increase in the volume of business being attracted to his office then something must suffer: either the standard of living of the solicitor must be reduced or else he has to cut costs somewhere. What is the way to cut costs? Any businessman or employer will know that in that kind of situation the only way to cut costs is to cut down on employment.

In connection with this order I wish to assert that we are not considering an irresponsible wage claim. We are considering here a formal order made by what must be one of the most responsible and certainly one of the most impartial and judicial cost fixing authorities in the country. The present order, as Senators will see by looking at it, is signed by the Chief Justice, the President of the High Court, a senior ordinary justice of the Supreme Court and the President of the Incorporated Law Society. The general order is made by and under the authority of the Statutory Body constituted under the Solicitors Remuneration Act, 1881. This body is composed, by that Act as adapted, of the Chief Justice, two senior judges and the President of the Incorporated Law Society.

The Minister pointed out the difference between contentious and non-contentious business. It is important to appreciate that we are not concerned in this order with court costs in any degree. Court costs, land registry costs, and Land Commission costs are dealt with by other rules committees. The scale of these costs, in order to become operative, require the concurrence of the Minister for Justice, with the exception of the Land Commission committee. At this point I wish to say that here is a vital distinction which goes to the very root of parliamentary responsibility. Court costs, by and large, are within the control of the Minister for Justice in so far as he has a concurring function in their making. The non-contentious costs, with which this order is concerned, are not within the control of the Minister for Justice. They are within the control of Parliament. That is a very important distinction.

I do not think any Member of this House can evade his own personal responsibility for coming to a decision on this matter by allowing himself to be said by the Minister on it. This is not a ministerial function. It is a matter which concerns each of us as individual Members of this House. The Act has placed the responsibility on us as Members of Parliament to take our own decisions and make up our own minds with regard to it. In those circumstances, I feel very strongly that this is not a matter which should in any sense be subject to a party whip. So far as the Members of my party in this House are concerned, they are not under any party whip with regard to this motion. They are quite free to vote against the case I am making and to argue against it. That is the proper approach to this matter because the responsibility is on each of us as individual Senators. The Minister expressed his regret in the course of his remarks at the action which he and the Government apparently consider themselves bound to take. He expressed the point of view that the Government would be lacking in their duty if they did not seek to have this order prohibited by Parliament.

I think it fair to ask the Minister why he is now taking that step, not having taken it in the Dáil where the Members are popularly elected. Why did he allow the Order, when it was placed on the Table of the Dáil, to go through unchallenged? Why did he wait until it came here to the Seanad? I put it to him—and I am putting it bluntly for the benefit of the Senators opposite—if the reason is because the Minister regards himself as having a built-in majority in the Seanad by reason of the nominations made to this House by the Taoiseach. I would deplore it very much if that was the reasoning behind the Minister's move. I do not think it right that any Senator, supporting the Government generally, should be placed in that position in a matter of this kind where he has individual responsibility. Even at this stage, I would urge the Minister to allow this matter to be the subject of a free vote. No application of a party whip will relieve individual Senators of their responsibility under the law as it stands.

It is relevant to note that the Statutory Body which has made this Order is, under the Act of 1881, entitled to have regard to particular considerations. These considerations include “the skill, labour and responsibility involved therein on the part of the solicitor”. They include the number and importance of the documents prepared or perused without regard to length. The personnel of this eminent Statutory Body, that is the Chief Justice, the President of the High Court, a senior Supreme Court judge and the President of the Incorporated Law Society, are particularly well suited by their specialised knowledge and experience and by their own training and expertise in these matters to assess and adjudicate on what is fair, just and reasonable as regards the solicitors' costs with which they deal. I know—and I am not saying this in any taunting manner—that the present Minister for Justice is a solicitor but this is merely a coincidence that happens from time to time. Normally speaking, the occupant of the ministerial chair in the Department of Justice would in no way be as well equipped or qualified to deal with the matters and items of costs dealt with in this order as would be the Chief Justice, the President of the High Court, the Supreme Court judge and the President of the Incorporated Law Society.

This eminent body, which is impartial and is virtually an entirely judicial tribunal, has decided that the appropriate increase in the items with which they are dealing would be 42 per cent on the level of fees fixed in 1964. That figure may appear to be high. It may be a reasonably easy exercise for the Minister to stand up in this House and ridicule the figure and to talk cautiously about the necessity to have regard to the views of other sections of the community, but there are a number of very important considerations that are relevant. However, there is one consideration which I regard as being entirely irrelevant and which was dragged in by the Minister presumably to colour the case he was making when he spoke about the conveyancing fees and costs paid to solicitors. This order has nothing, good, bad or indifferent, to do with conveyancing fees.

There are some considerations that are both important and relevant to this discussion. One of those relevant considerations is that there have been six rounds of wage increases since 1961. Those wage increases, together with other increases such as increased postal charges, telephone charges, electricity charges and increases in other items and services which are used by a solicitor in his business, operate automatically to increase the office expenses of solicitors.

I shall give an example of this as regards my own office. I know that one cannot, in a matter of this sort, argue from the particular to the general, but if the Minister cares to make inquiries among solicitors of his acquaintance and if he cares to examine the figures in his own office, before he reached ministerial status, he will find that the figures I am about to quote here are reasonably typical. I am giving figures for certain items from certified accounts in my office for the year ended 31st December, 1963. and the year ended 31st December. 1969. Those accounts are not selective. So far as the 1969 figure is concerned, I am giving it because it was the last certified account available to me at the time I undertook this examination. My reason for taking the year 1963 is because my firm moved offices in 1962 and if I went back to make a comparison, as I would have preferred to do, with the year ending 31st December, 1960, or 31st December, 1961, I would be misleading the House because I would not, in some instances, be comparing like with like. With the change of offices certain matters such as rates, light and heat were on a different scale and volume. It would be much more in my favour to go back to the earlier years and give the figures for them but as this is not possible the figures I am giving for the later year are more suited to the Minister's case than mine.

I find, taking those two comparisons —the year ended 31st December, 1963, and the year ended 31st December. 1969—that accountancy charges have increased by more than 150 per cent. The cost of printing, postage and stationery have increased by more than 56 per cent. Rent and rates have increased by more than 71 per cent. That, of course, would be nearly exclusively rates because, talking from recollection, the rent was only a ground rent and would have been static. Light and heat have increased during that period by more than 52 per cent and salaries have increased by more than 100 per cent. So that on those five items within the shorter span of time that I am taking—the six-year span— the average increase under those five headings has been something more than 85 per cent in my office and I think you will find, if you care to make inquiry, that that is probably typical as regards size of any reasonably equivalent solicitors' office.

It is also relevant to point out in this connection that every Senator got a very reasonably worded and courteous letter from the President of the Incorporated Law Society, enclosing the memorandum which was submitted to the Minister, I think, on 3rd January last, and which received no comment from the Minister. Those documents will satisfy every Member of the House. If you place the solicitor's profession side by side with a number of other categories, the solicitor's profession has certainly fared very ill. Between the years 1961 and 1971 the cost of living increase has been 74 per cent. Compensatory increases have been given to higher civil servants averaging 85 per cent during that period. Judicial salaries have been increased by 100 per cent during the period. TD's allowances have been increased by 150 per cent during the period mentioned and the allowances of Members of this House have been increased by 100 per cent.

How did the highly-paid solicitors mentioned by the Minister in his opening address this afternoon fare during that particular period? It is the responsibility of each of us to consider this and to make up his own mind on it. If one looks at the solicitors' item charges for that period it can be seen —taking 1962, not 1961, as a base— that the Superior Court costs went up by 12 per cent; the Circuit Court costs went up by nil; the District Court costs were increased by 12 per cent; non-contentious business items of cost were increased by 12 per cent and land registry costs were not increased. The only reasonably substantial increase— from 1965, not from 1961—was in the fees payable under the criminal legal aid scheme, which is of limited scope and of very limited applicability so far as the general body of solicitors is concerned. These fees went up by 25 per cent. That is the position.

What is the position of other professions? At the outset I said, as did the Minister in his opening speech, that the solicitors' profession is the only one that is controlled as regards fees and costs. Every other profession has been able, during the period of which I speak, to make its own adjustments. In the circular which Senators received from the President of the Incorporated Law Society an example is given of one other profession. For two years—1970 and 1971—a typical accountant's fee of £300 in 1970 rose to £500 in 1971, and was justified on a time cost basis. I am not in any sense endeavouring to denigrate other professions or to say that whatever increased allowances, costs or fees they received were not justified and warranted. I am merely mentioning this point in order to show the differentiation in treatment as between the profession to which I have the honour of being a member and other professions. While I am on the point, I have here the scales recommended by the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Ireland on two dates: those that were recommended in September, 1968, and those recommended in July, 1970. That is only a two-year period. I should like to give some comparison between the fees that are recommended. Of course they are not necessarily limited to this or are not necessarily maximum fees: they are simply recommended fees in particular circumstances.

I should like members to look at the order that we are considering now. It is not very easy for a non-solicitor to follow, because the order is made—I assume that this is the usual way of doing it—by reference to particular items under Schedule 2 of the general order. These items cover a number of things. I want to take particularly three items: item No. 8, of which the increase was from £1.12 to £1.60; item No. 8 relates to perusing accounts and rentals per hour, in other words, it is a time cost basis for a particular job. What is ordered by the Statutory Body is that the fee in that should be increased from £1.12 to £1.60.

I want to refer to two others, Nos. 12 and 13. The reason why I am referring to these will become clear later. No. 12 is the attendance fee for an attendance in a solicitor's office for the first half-hour. No. 13 is the attendance fee in a solicitor's office for each subsequent half-hour, so that if you add items 12 and 13 together, you will get the fee which a solicitor may charge for an hour's attendance in his own office. This order increases item 12 from £1.12 to £1.59, that is, for the first half-hour. It increases No. 13 from 84p to £1.19, that is, for the second half-hour. If you put the two together you get the hourly charge which may be made and it works out at £2.78.

I want to compare those figures: No. 8, which is an hourly charge for doing a particular job in the office and the Nos. 12 and 13 combined, which give the hourly charge for the first hour for an attendance in the office, and remember, it is reducing after the first half-hour. In regard to No. 8; the recommended charge for the time-cost basis of working on accounts and rents for an hour in a solicitor's office is £1.60. If one compares that with the recommendations from the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Ireland—this is given, per day in a day of seven hours and I have broken it down into an hourly cost basis—the principal's time on an hourly basis recommended in 1968 was £4.18. The principal's time recommended in July, 1970, on an hourly basis is £6, that is, for a principal doing general supervisory work. A principal's time for work other than general supervisory work in September, 1968, was about £3.07, and in July, 1970, £4.60. Managers or principal assistants in September, 1968, were paid about £3.07, in July, 1970, £4.60. Senior assistants in July, 1968, were paid about £2.11. Solicitors are way down the scale as compared with the recommendations of the Chartered Accountants Institute. Junior assistants in July, 1968, under the Chartered Accountants recommended scale, got about £1 and in July, 1970, it ranged from £1 to £1.60.

That is a fair comparison. The position is that, on the basis of those figures, even the most senior and most experienced solicitor in the largest solicitor's office in this country fares extremely poorly by comparison with managers, principal assistants or senior assistants in the office of a chartered accountant, because they can be charged at a rate per hour ranging from nearly £1 per hour to more than £3 per hour. When you compare it with the principal on general advisory work, of course the solicitor, despite his qualifications and the importance of the work he may be concerned with, despite the volume of business which he may be required to handle and control, is simply nowhere in the race.

Another comparison I should like to make is this. I am not going to mention the name but I have here a copy of an account which was submitted by a firm. I want to describe them generally as civil and structural engineers because I do not want to identify them as I have not got their permission to do so. I should imagine that they are working on a recommended scale also. This was an account presented in December, 1970, and it shows that the charge per hour for the senior partner in that firm was £5.25, as compared with a maximum of £2.78 for the first hour for a solicitor, which is only being recommended now. This shows also that the technician's hourly charge, in this particular firm, was £1.05 an hour, a rate very much the equivalent of what the solicitor has been allowed up to this.

Anyone considering this matter and the very reasonable case which has been made to Senators by the Incorporated Law Society concerning the facts, items, figures and percentages which I have given—and I believe they are incontrovertible facts, not in any way exaggerated or slanted to suit the case I am making—will agree with me that this order made by this very responsible and important body is one which should be upheld by this House. Certainly I would urge Senators to accept that they have individual responsibility in this matter. If they are convinced by the case which the Minister has made, then by all means, their duty is to vote for the Minister to disallow this order. If they feel that, on balance, the weight of the argument is against the Minister, as I feel it most emphatically is, then I think the duty of individual Senators is to reject this motion, regardless of which side of this House they may sit.

Speaker.P: I find myself in a difficult position here in deciding which way I should vote on this issue. I have read the literature which we have received. First of all, there is the Statutory Order, the Solicitors' Remuneration General Order which we are discussing. I find without doing a great deal of further work that this particular order does not mean anything to someone who is not a solicitor, because there is no explanatory memorandum to point out which items are being referred to and to explain in a more general way what the changes will mean. I feel this should have been done by the body which drew up this statutory instrument. Also I found it difficult to follow precisely what the Minister said. It was so technical that without a script it was just not possible to take it all in, absorb it and then get some sort of balanced view of his remarks. It is a great disappointment to me that we were not given copies of the Minister's speech, because I just got lost about half way through trying to figure out——
Copies were of course given out. I am sorry if the Senator did not get one. The official must have overlooked the Senator.
I apologise to the Minister.
I am sorry the Senator did not get it earlier. He should have got it. I had copies for every Senator.

I made signals towards the door with no effect, so I presumed that no copies were available, and I apologise to the Minister. I feel I should respond to what Senator O'Higgins has said in that I must make a judgment on this issue. I feel it is an extremely important issue. The salaries of a whole group of people are involved, a large and very important profession, and it is clear from the Statutory Instrument or from some of the other documents with which we have been issued by the Incorporated Law Society—who have not been slow in issuing documents on this and quite rightly so too—that the fees in question have not been changed for a considerable period of time. I should like to refer again to one of the documents issued by the Incorporated Law Society and to reiterate how difficult it is for someone who is not a solicitor to judge the particular issue. In a document which I received dated 18th February, 1972, there is discussion of the salaries and increases in salaries of the various professions and of members of the legal profession, Members of the Dáil and Seanad, the higher civil servants and the judicial salaries. Various comparisons are made. There is also a comparison of the rise in the cost of living between 1961 and 1971, from base 100 in 1961 to a figure of 174 in November, 1971.

However, when one is trying to assess what is a fair salary in these situations, we have got to have some figures of what range of salaries solicitors actually get. It is not enough to have a base figure of 100 and say that the cost of living has gone up to 174 points from 100 points. One must know what the actual salaries involved are or at least have a reasonable range given by which one can judge what the solicitors' maximum salary might be, what the minimum salary might be, which is probably more important, and also what would be the salary earned by the average solicitor in the country. These figures are essential and we were not issued with them at all. How then does one compare the solicitors' salaries with the salaries of the other professions, the academic profession like my own whose salaries are controlled by the Government through the Department of Education, and quite rightly so? We are in a negotiable position and negotiations continue and our salaries change. Also how would one compare the salaries of the solicitors with, say, salaries of people in the medical profession? Again without actual figures it is very difficult to make any accurate judgment.

It is my impression that the solicitors are not badly off. I have not met solicitors who failed to make a living. Most of the solicitors I know are doing well—perhaps an unrepresentative selection. On the other hand, this does not mean that the solicitors are keeping pace with other professions. The indications from the figures given by the Incorporated Law Society are that they are not, but this is only an indication. If we do not know the actual base figure from which we are working this is all meaningless. For example, supposing a solicitor was earning £10,000 a year, then the cost of living index increase probably would not affect him very much, but this is the problem which we are faced with.

MainHeading.P: I will carefully go through the Minister's speech and try and understand the gist of it now that I have got a copy. But I feel that in respect of fees which have not been increased since 1961 solicitors have a very strong case. On the other hand, I can quite see any Government baulking at having to authorise increases of 42 per cent. It strikes me that the only just solution is a long-term one which is apart from this particular issue, and that is, the working out of a fair and just incomes policy to which people should adhere. That does not get over the present problem in relation to which we are being asked to authorise specific increases through this order. Even though the solicitors' case is strong, in that since 1961 these fees have not been increased and they therefore ask for an increase of 42 per cent I feel that this is asking for too much in present circumstances. I would have been happier had they asked for a figure which was considerably less than 42 per cent and some compromise on this has been struck. However, the body which has drawn up this statutory instrument is obviously a body which contains very distinguished people. The people who have signed the instrument are all well known, all people whose integrity would be above suspicion, but we must remember that they are members of the legal profession and, like any other profession, tend to band together to protect their own interests. Of course one of the things that they clearly will do is to protect their financial interests.

My point really is that it is very difficult for an individual making up his mind independently to judge this issue. I rather sympathise with the Minister in that he is a member of the profession himself and therefore is in some sense taken to be adjudicating a case in which he is personally involved. I feel that on occasions like this people who are fair-minded tend to be rather too hard on the body in which they are personally involved. That is just my personal experience. I feel worried about this. The cases that have been put are absolutely divergent and I guess that if there was a Labour Court situation some sort of compromise would be reached which would not satisfy all the aims of both parties but would at least satisfy some of the aims of both parties. I must say that the documentation which we have received has not helped to put me completely in the picture, and I feel that we could have had more information of a comparative nature and this would certainly have helped me to make up my mind on this issue.

Speaker.P: It is most important that no section of the public should have incomes out of proportion to any other section. It is equally important that everybody should be dealt with fairly, objectively and impartially. The Minister has stressed in his speech that the decision of the Statutory Body consisting of the Chief Justice, the President of the High Court, the Senior Judge of the Supreme Court and one member from the legal profession—the President of the Law Society—should be subject to statutory control. May I say that the solicitors' profession welcomes at all times statutory control, that is, control by either or both Houses of Parliament, who are the custodians of the public good.

As far back as 1962—and that is nine years ago—the solicitors' profession suggested that, instead of the various committees to which the Minister has referred, there be one committee for dealing with all aspects of a solicitor's remuneration. If it were felt that the Statutory Body that was dealing with them was not adequately acquainted with the practical aspects of life, then the solicitors recommended that this body should contain members of the general public who would be in a position to arrive at an objective judgment; that it would include— though not in the majority—some members of the solicitors' profession; that it would include persons who were acquainted with what solicitors' remuneration is and what their expenses are. It is absolutely impossible to give an average, as Senator West has asked. Some men are barely able to struggle along with the assistance of their wives doing the typing or with the assistance of one or two typists. Other men acting for large corporations who want everything done yesterday are prepared to pay accordingly and, in fact, to offer those fees in advance if necessary.

MainHeading.P: You cannot arrive at an average. It is important that the remuneration should be reasonable and that this committee, therefore, should include people who are acquainted with what the average solicitor earns, having regard to the amount of work he does, what his expenses are and what is left for himself to live on. For this reason it is suggested that this committee should include representatives of accountants who audit solicitors' fees. It should include also representatives of the public who have experience of dealing with solicitors and possibly even people in a substantial way of business. We suggested that the evidence before such a body could, if possible, be given in public and be given by people who had experience of these matters and who would be qualified to advise such a body, and that whatever that body decided upon would be binding on us as a profession, but subject to the overriding obligation of the Oireachtas, who are the custodians of the public good, if they saw fit, to say, that it was too high.

That was the suggestion we made and that was a suggestion we did not wait until now to make. So far from objecting to control from the Oireachtas, we welcome that control and we like control by the Oireachtas and by the Oireachtas only. We feel that in all matters where incomes, divisions in incomes or reductions in incomes or anything else arise, these matters too should be subject to the control of the Oireachtas. I doubt if there is one other profession in this country that would make such a suggestion or such a case. I respectfully submit that.

We have no choice in this matter. We are governed by the statute as it exists. The statute as it exists is that this Statutory Body shall be the Chief Justice, the President of the High Court, a Senior Judge of the Supreme Court and the President of the Law Society. Where matters in dispute regarding income are submitted to a body I think that the employers—even when the employers are representative of the general public—usually take the body to be impartial. There is no reason in the world why people who are accustomed to being conservative, who represent the public good, who safeguard the general public, such as judges of the High Court or the Supreme Court, should be unfair to anybody. Perhaps they are. I am not saying that the Minister is not perfectly correct in what he says. If that is the view of the Government the Oireachtas would, as he says, be failing in their duty if they did not oppose their decision. Prima facie, I would have imagined that they would be fair.

The Minister has stated that the question of solicitors' fees has come up and they have been increased from time to time. This would leave a person listening under the impression that they had been increased every two or three years. In 1960 there was an increase. Between 1960 and 1972 there was one increase. There was an increase in 1964 of 12 per cent relating to these particular items. From 1964 to date there has been no increase in those items. Perhaps the Minister is right in saying that there should not be an increase. In the meantime, of course, there have been six increases in the remuneration of the staff of solicitors' offices. They are also governed by arbitration, and when the arbitration decides this decision is accepted. The arbitration body consists of representatives of the solicitors, representatives of the staffs and an independent chairman. The independent chairman usually decides.

Between 1964 and the present time there have been enormous increases in rents. Every solicitor must get his accounts audited, and the fees for this have been increased. There have been increases in his insurances. This year alone fire insurance has gone up by 40 per cent and a solicitor must take out very heavy insurance because if documents belonging to clients are destroyed he will be in serious trouble. If he carries a large amount of money on hands for clients, or if his ledgers or accounts are destroyed, he must be heavily insured against those things. I noticed when I got my own bill for insurances last month that they had increased by 40 per cent during the past 12 months.

Other increases one has to meet are postage, stationery, repairs, replacement of typewriters and so on. We can take it on average that those increases were not less than increases in the cost of living, that is about 74 per cent between 1964 and the present. Despite that, it may be felt, objectively, that solicitors should not get 42 per cent. One would imagine that the Statutory Body would possibly have given 74 per cent. Judges are a conservative body and are entitled to feel that, if things were let slide for the last six or seven years, this is all they can do. I think, however, they originally considered and made this offer some 12 months ago.

The Minister has stated that instructions fees, which are a substantial item in a solicitor's bill, have increased with the cost of living. I agree with the Minister. The implication there might be that there is a suggestion that this instructions fee should be increased by 42 per cent. This is not so. If one item in a solicitor's bill increases by 42 per cent, unless they were overpaid in 1964 to make sure they are not overpaid at the present time in case they were overpaid in 1964, the other items should not increase. The suggestion was that the decision in 1964 to increase fees by 12 per cent for a period of four years was not excessive and, therefore the increase in the instructions fee has no bearing on the items under consideration.

The Minister also refers to scale fees on sales and states that these increase in proportion to the amount of the sale. This is perfectly correct so far as it goes, but they do not increase in direct proportion; they increase on a sliding scale. I am dealing with the sale, at the moment, of a licenced public-house including an acre of land in County Tipperary. The purchase price is £6,300. I have had a good deal of work negotiating this. The auctioneer had it advertised for quite a long time. There were people coming into my office making inquiries and so on. My actual scale fee for this is £74.75 because the scale reduces by approximately £1.25 per £100. The sale which a solicitor gets is like getting money from America. You do not have substantial sales every day of the week. According to the Minister's speech I am being overpaid. After the place is sold, and I have had all these interviews in advance, I have to submit the contract, get requisitions on title and deal with them. I have to get the deed completed. I must arrange for the transfer of the licence and so on. Perhaps I am overpaid at £74.75. I do not know. Personally I would find it difficult to believe this.

Again, dealing with these sale fees, the Minister has stated that the value of property and of lands has increased considerably more than the cost of living. He is quite correct there. If a solicitor sells a house, which is not in the Land Registry, for £10,000, he would feel like taking his wife to a party that night. He has been very lucky that day. For all the work in connection with that sale, assuming that it is not in the Land Registry, which involves going through a maze of title deeds, to satisfy the purchaser to whom he is selling, or to go through all the title deeds, prepare the deed of conveyance, stamp and register it and so on, the solicitor's fee is £200. If a farm is involved and, as frequently happens, the owner is there for 20 years so the equities can be readily discharged, the fee is £102.50 on a sale for £10,000. These sales are, so to speak, plums.

Supposing it is a very big farm and goes over £10,000 and up to £20,000, for every £1,000 the solicitor gets an additional £3.75, if it is registered for over 20 years and you can get equities discharged. Therefore, for the extra £10,000 he gets £37.50 on top of his £102.50. That makes £140. I agree this pays and I am very happy when I get it. Perhaps it is excessive, as the Minister has stated. That is a matter of opinion. There is no application to increase those fees.

In connection with this pub I sold, one firm of auctioneers who advertised it wanted 5 per cent on the sale and their advertising expenses, which on £6,300 was £315 plus their advertising expenses. To add insult to injury, when they went to sell, another firm of auctioneers had a letter from a prospective purchaser in England and they would only introduce the prospective purchaser on condition that they got 5 per cent also—£315. I have not yet paid either of them. I have put the money on deposit receipt. I got £6,300 plus the £315 auctioneer's commission which I have put on deposit receipt to see exactly what I can do because I rather object to paying them £315 apiece.

The client in question is an old and valued one and in the hope that he would not get involved in litigation I offered to do the work for nothing and to make the second firm of auctioneers who introduced the purchaser a gift of £74.75 which was my fee. I simply give those figures as some of the practical objective points.

The Minister has said that most parts of the solicitor's business can be said to be reasonably remunerative. That depends to a great extent on the type of business you do. If you are acting for a wealthy man who wants a thing done thoroughly and quickly and is prepared to pay you whatever you demand that is fine. The man with one or two typists and a wife and four or five children dependant on him gets the average client who does not want to pay a shilling more than he should.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Fitzgerald Mr. J. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: He would have to join a political party.

I merely make that point. He hopes that sometime his practice will improve and he will get regular fees. I sympathise with the Minister. The legal profession have been very remiss and they have let things run since 1964. As the Minister has pointed out, if the average worker feels that the solicitor is getting an increase of 42 per cent he will see red. He will not consider that since 1964 the solicitor has got no increase in these items. Taking my own practice, which I would consider to be reasonably average, the items here would probably cover approximately 70 per cent of my income, except the instructions fee.

MainHeading.P: I wish to be fair to the Minister. The instructions fee has increased with the cost of living but there is no application to increase that. There should be a levelling up rather than a levelling down. I should like to see the income of the poor man, the worker, the small salary earner coming up at a much more rapid percentage than the incomes of others. In one way I cannot speak for the profession in that I am not dependent on my income from the profession. Other aspects of my income have increased.

I have tried to explain the facts as fairly and as objectively as I can. I think it is difficult when nothing has been done for seven or eight years— whether that is the fault of the Law Society I do not know—to come along to the Minister and say: “Look, here is the situation. We find a large number of solicitors, especially men in small offices, are unable to get along. What can we do if they overcharge and they say they must overcharge in order to live. If they charge more than the scale fees how can we penalise them?” If you make your statutory charges too low they will be ignored. If they are ignored it is the dishonest men who will suffer least. This is the difficulty as I see it.

It is unfortunate that this large increase has been put together this way. Perhaps the reason that the Law Society do not come forward every two or three years is because naturally judges are slow to make decisions They have public responsibility. When the decisions are made they have to be submitted to the Minister's Department. They have to be considered for a long time and there is usually a lapse of an average of two or three years in many of the applications for increases. I have tried to put the facts objectively. I have endeavoured not to lean in any direction. I visualise the Minister's sense of responsibility, if he and the Government are convinced they would be failing in their duty if they granted this increase. The real issue is: is this increase unfair in these circumstances? If their expenses have gone up 74 per cent in those circumstances is the increase excessive?

Speaker.P: I should like to say a few words on this subject on which I find myself not very competent to speak. In order to weigh the scales as fairly as possible and, having listened to the case made by the Minister to disallow the order and listened to the cases made by Senators O'Higgins, Nash and West, I should like to contribute what I hope will be some helpful remarks. As a nonmember of the legal profession and one who from time to time has had reason to use the services of the legal profession, as I see it purely on the basis of an increase based on a scale of fees last fixed in 1964, almost eight years ago, the request for an increase of 42 per cent strikes me as not being unreasonable.

There are very few salaries, wages and other sources of remuneration that have not increased by substantially more than 42 per cent in the past eight years. Examples have been given by Senators O'Higgins and Nash to indicate that other sectors of the public have received justified increases very substantially in excess of 42 per cent. If there were no other relevant factors in the case I feel that the Minister and the Government would accept it.

The Minister has introduced the question of the reward to the solicitors from other types of work which they do. In his speech he has mentioned two in particular, the higher amounts allowable under the head of instructions which he defines as a fee at large and, secondly, the increase in property values which has brought a substantial increase in remuneration to solicitors for conveyancing, as costs are related on an ad valorem basis to the value of property conveyed.

I am at a loss, as I am sure other Members of the House must be, in trying to decide if the increases under the latter two headings make up for the losses which solicitors incurred as a result of the increased costs of running their offices. Is the income under the heading of “instructions” and from conveyancing increased to such an extent that it will offset those losses? The Minister has not produced any figures to suggest that this is so.

MainHeading.P: I was very impressed by the case made by Senator Nash and I find myself influenced, to a large extent, by the points he made. There must be a substantial difference in the remuneration accruing to a solicitor in a good city practice and the remuneration accruing to a solicitor in a rural area. I have had some experience of solicitors practising in rural areas and one example stands out in my memory. Following the death of a rural solicitor it became almost impossible to sell his practice. Finally, one buyer came forward who purchased the practice at his own price. Nobody could contend that such a solicitor was getting a remuneration commensurate with his profession. The remuneration of solicitors is a very difficult matter for an ordinary layman to adjudicate on. To complicate the task still further there are three bodies dealing with the question of solicitors' remuneration.

Speaker.P: Five bodies.

That augments the Minister's own case and makes it even more confusing for people such as myself. I would echo the Minister's plea and Senator Nash's plea that some consolidation or rationalisation of the bodies involved with solicitors' costs should be undertaken. The Minister in his speech said that the Government were not totally opposed to an increase in solicitors' remuneration but they were not prepared to accept an unreasonable increase. The Minister then went on to compare costs in this country under certain headings with comparable costs in Great Britain, Scotland and Northern Ireland. Again, I must admit to being unable to grasp the comparison because the figures were not produced. It is very hard for a layman such as myself, who has a very high regard for solicitors' competence and integrity, to know which side to take.

MainHeading.P: The cost of law generally to the litigant is increasing very rapidly and at some future time something will have to be done to keep costs within limits. Perhaps the answer to that problem lies, as the Minister said recently, in the coming together of the legal professions something along the lines of the system in the United States. Without doubt, the cost of law is becoming excessive to the ordinary public. I do not lay the blame for that on the shoulders of the legal profession as this trend has been apparent for some years.

On balance I think the solicitors have made a good case for the increases. I sympathise with the Minister as he has a responsibility towards the community but I am not convinced that the Minister has made a sufficiently good case to justify my supporting him on this order. An order seeking to recoup costs incurred eight years ago cannot be considered unreasonable. The Minister has not proved that solicitors' remuneration arising under other headings is sufficient to offset the increased costs incurred by them during the past eight years.

Speaker.P: I do not intend to delay the House very long because much of what I intended to say has already been said by Senator West. I find myself largely in agreement with what he said. We are in rather an extraordinary position as Members of this House because we are trying to arbitrate on a pay claim. In many respects Senators find themselves acting as advocates, counter-advocates and arbitrators. It is difficult to arrive at a proper balanced decision in such a situation.

MainHeading.P: From what other speakers have said I am more convinced than ever that the entire situation has got into a horrible knot and I cannot see how they are going to extricate themselves from it. Perhaps the blame can be laid on both sides in the past for what has resulted in the present impasse. Having had some experience of wage and salary negotiations and having sat on arbitration boards, may I say with respect to the learned gentlemen on both sides that if either side in normal wage negotiations, where the chairman of the arbitration board is generally a rather eminent gentleman from the legal profession, presented their case in the way in which it has been presented to this House the chairman of the arbitration board would have no option but to say: “I think we will have to adjourn and do a little more homework on both sides and come back before I could make my decision.” We are all anxious that justice be done to the people who are seeking this increase but we also have to look at the other side of the case. We must think not only of the general good but on the case as presented by the Minister. I have difficulty in understanding it. It is obviously a very complicated matter which requires some study and a great deal of expertise, but having five bodies to adjudicate on different parts of the solicitors' remuneration seems to be quite extraordinary in the year 1972. Here we seem to be dealing with one of those bodies but I am not clear as to what increases members of the profession may have received since 1964 from the other four-fifths of the relevant bodies.

Speaker.P: Twelve per cent of this sum; 25 per cent on free legal aid. That is all.
No, not at all.
On the actual increases.
Your clients make the case that 70 per cent of their remuneration is in this one-fifth which complicates matters still further.
Yes, but there was only 10 per cent on this since 1961.
No, instructions fees in the High Court, for example, is the bulk of it. I will deal with it in the reply.
Abandon the triangular conversation, please. Senator Owens to continue.

It illustrated the point very clearly. Suddenly I found I was almost acting as chairman of an arbitration board between the Minister and the advocate on the other side. It is not so simple: there is an awful lot more that could be argued on both sides of the case. I agree very much with Senator West when he made the point about the Statutory Body that deal with this, made up of the Chief Justice, the President of the High Court, a senior judge of the Supreme Court and the President of the Incorporated Law Society of Ireland. I do not for one minute doubt the integrity of these gentlemen. However, in the present state of advancement of industrial relations in this country, I think it is extraordinary that people within the profession should be adjudging the remuneration of their own profession. I should imagine there would be quite a howl and cry from the business world if we had a board of dockers who decided what increase the men on the docks should get.
Not from the dockers, surely.

I said it was from the business world the howl would be. Obviously, this is something that is wrong. It is not unusual for professional people to appear before independent arbitration boards. The engineers have done it; the Irish Medical Union do it quite regularly in the area where they are negotiating salaries and fees. I should like to see this type of negotiation system applied to the Law Society. Senator Nash pointed out that some years ago they made a proposal——
Nine years ago.
Nine years ago, and to date this has not been taken up. This is a disgrace.
That is not entirely fair to the Minister. There have been negotiations.

Negotiations, but obviously they have not been finalised, or we should not be in this morass today. The Minister also pointed out that this particular order could not be considered in isolation. It must be viewed as part of a general claim being pursued at present by the Incorporated Law Society for considerable increases in costs, both in contentious and non-contentious business. Frankly, we have not heard anything as to what that might be, what the extent of it is, what percentage or whether it is a percentage. Again, all I can do is put a query after it. I should like to know, and if we have any way of getting the information it would be of value to people in trying to make a judgment on it.

One of the real problems we are facing is that one must either accept or reject it: there is no way of amending the order. This is an extraordinary situation for any arbitrators to be in, because what you can normally do is liable to be the result of a concensus and you must hope it is agreed on both sides.
This originated in 1881, unfortunately.

From 1881 to 1972 is an awful long time. I do not know of any trade union that would have put up with a situation that had continued for so long. I would say to the Law Society: “For goodness sake, get your house put into order: you are well able to do it.” I am afraid that Senator O'Higgins's interruptions make me sound a little stronger than I probably intended to be.

The other big factor that must be taken into account is the general good and the fact that the last national wage agreement which is still operating, has confined the ordinary worker to £2 per week, with a follow-up of 4 per cent. Two pounds a week was quite deliberately negotiated as being a way of bringing up the lower paid worker, which is a principle that everyone in this House would agree with. The tendency now in negotiations, both from the employer and the employee, is to go away from percentage increases, because they have never worked to the benefit of the lower paid worker, and they never will. There is no way of bringing up the lower paid worker or of getting an equitable distribution of income, and this is what we should be anxious to do, if percentage incomes are to be proceeded with.

MainHeading.P: I have wandered more than I intended to. On balance, I must say that I would support rejection of the order. It is not that I am satisfied entirely with the reasons for rejecting it, because I do not think all the facts have been put before the House, and I would do it solely for this reason. We should give enough impetus to both sides to get together to sort out a proper way and one that would conform with the procedures that obtain normally when negotiating salaries, fees and wages.

Speaker.P: I should like to oppose this order. The case has been made that solicitors have not received an increase for some time. However, most of the business conducted by solicitors is in connection with sales and transfers of property. Everybody knows how much that has increased during the past ten years, and solicitors get a percentage of the money. Solicitors and auctioneers are the only people who work completely on a percentage basis and, with higher values, they are getting a much better income.
They do not work on a percentage basis on conveyances.
On some accounts they do.
It is a fixed scale.
It is a percentage.
It is a percentage. If you buy——
It may average out as a percentage but it is not a percentage scale.
The Senator naturally gets a very small percentage.
If you are speaking about auctioneers, they are on a percentage, but solicitors are not: there is a sliding scale.
As far as I remember, it is usually around 2 or 3 per cent.
I have the book here. I will give it to the Senator.
Anyway, it is going up. There is another item which I know——
It is not going up. There will be no alteration.
Do not interrupt Senator Crinion—he is getting on fine. He is dead on the ball. Leave him alone.
I think that in the country——
In fact, it is going down considerably because of compulsory registration.
Senator Crinion on the motion.

There are many people building houses as a result of the government's policy of helping them. All those loans are going through the solicitors' hands and the costs are quite substantial. It is a business that did not exist ten years ago, or to a very small extent. I suppose 99 per cent of all those people getting married today must consult a solicitor before they apply for loans for their new houses. That is a business that never existed before and is comparatively simple. In Dublin it usually consists of dealings with the builder who acquires sites for houses. It is simply a question of transferring the property and can be carried out in bulk. The solicitors then collect their fees for such transfers. I have never heard of a solicitor whose work was done overnight. It is usually carried on over a period of months and a long time elapses before he sends a bill. If it was a business, the account would come out every month. A solicitor never makes out his account until the business deal is completed, so he is obviously never short of money. Most of them are progressing quite favourably. If anything their offices are getting bigger. In that regard there is no justification for a 42 per cent increase. Some years ago when we received our own increase there was a great deal of opposition and the public and trade unions maintained that——
Only 100 per cent for Senators. Deputies got 150 per cent.

It was 60 per cent for Senators and it came after a long time. If this increase is granted the general public will take a very poor view of it. As a profession they do not have very good public relations and therefore they could not expect to have a 42 per cent increase without having to put up any case, except to one of their own members. They do not have to appear before an independent tribunal so it is only right that they should put their case to us before receiving an increase in order that we may express the opinions of the general public. In this respect I feel that this very substantial increase should be rejected.

May I correct something I said to Senator Crinion? He is correct in one sense in referring to the rise in fees as being a percentage but in fact it is a sliding scale with the percentage fixed per thousand and it varies from thousand to thousand.
Still, property is going up steadily.

The impasse here shows the necessity for an overall look at the situation. It is no justification to say that increases under one heading should not be allowed because charges under other headings are extravagant. I admit that charges under other headings are quite extravagant in that the whole question of fees —whether auctioneers' fees or some of the transfer fees charged by solicitors —are out of keeping with the amount of work involved. On the other hand, the fees which were adequate in 1969 and which come under the present order obviously are not adequate today. It highlights this tardiness in bringing fees and payments for many sections into line with the decrease in the value of money.

We are now faced—as we were in the case of the Oireachtas salaries— with what certainly appears to be a completely exorbitant increase due to the fact that regular increases were not given over the years. If all wages were paid at the 1962 level and suddenly had to be raised to today's level the increase in most of them would be of the order of at least 100 per cent, if account were taken of devaluation and the economic improvement that has taken place since then.
The Prices Bill promised by the Government is long overdue and it may bring order into this field.

MainHeading.P: It is difficult at this stage to judge whether a 42 per cent increase is justified. On the other hand, some of the other increases, based on percentages, whether it is on a sliding or whatever other scale, are inordinate for the amount of work done. At the head of that, the auctioneers stand the most culpable of all. Consequently I welcome the Minister's declared intention of rationalising those fees in the Prices Bill. We look forward to the debate on that.

In the meantime the Minister has set his face against this increase. Therefor, I hope that arising out of the rejection of the order the Minister will get together with the profession concerned and will try to rationalise and relieve some of the burden of the inordinate charges they have made under other headings in conveyance of land, property and other things which are totally exorbitant today.

Speaker.P: The topic which we have been discussing for the last two hours is a complex and highly complicated one. It is a topic that is not understood even by some solicitors. In many of the larger offices many solicitors would not have a great deal to do with costs and so would not know a great deal about them. In view of the fact that there are quite a number of solicitors who do not understand the complexity of the topic we have had under discussion today, it is not surprising that laymen and women find it difficult to understand it. I sympathise with their predicament. I am sorry that my opening speech was so technical that lay Members of the House found it difficult to follow, but unfortunately if one is to deal objectively and fairly with this topic one has to try and spell it out accurately and at great length.

As I have said already, there are quite a few solicitors who do not understand very much about costs. I might add that it has often been said to me that no barrister knows the first thing about solicitors' costs. This highlights still further the problem that a non-lawyer must have in trying to understand what we are talking about here today.

MainHeading.P: Because the matter is so complex and difficult to understand, it is unfortunately very easy to be misleading in regard to it. There was a fair amount of misleading done today, although I am not suggesting it was intentional. It is little wonder, therefore, that uncommitted Members of the House, who seek to do justice to both sides, would find a lot of difficulty in making up their minds. I am sorry that some of the Senators who expressed difficulty in understanding the matter are not in the House any longer because I would like to try to deal with the points they raised and to try to clear up the difficulties they had in understanding the whole affair.

I did not want to refer to a memorandum sent out by the Law Society to, I understand, all Senators, because I have an objection to private pressure groups trying to put their points of view across. To refer to such documents as private pressure groups may put out is only to add a certain dignity to them and this is something I do not wish to do. This memorandum, which is dated 3rd January, 1972 was handed to me by a member of the Law Society on 5th January with the request that I should read it—not that I should comment on it. However, Senator O'Higgins has criticised me for not commenting on it today.

So far as that memorandum is concerned I want to say straight away that it is misleading in two respects. It picks out certain items and gives figures in respect of them. However, these items are by no means representative as they relate to only a small fraction of what is really involved and the very large increases in the other items have been totally ignored.

Even allowing for this distortion, there are, on the face of it, at least two blatant errors in the percentage increases in relation to solicitors' item charges shown on page 2 of this memorandum. One is the statement that between 1961 and 1971 there was no increase in costs in the Circuit Court. That of course is untrue: there was an increase of 20 per cent in 1967.

This memorandum also has a statement that whereas the Criminal Legal Aid Scheme had a base of 100 in 1965, it was 125 in November, 1971, and that the increase in that period was, therefore, 25 per cent. In fact, the increase was slightly more than 60 per cent: it averages out at about 62 or 63 per cent. I am very familiar with these figures because I was involved in the negotiating of that increase. It is very disturbing to my mind that the Law Society would send out figures such as these to Senators, who no doubt accept them in good faith, when in fact the figures are totally wrong. I made an order in October, 1970 increasing criminal legal aid fees by slightly more than 60 per cent. Notwithstanding this, the figure that is given in the memorandum is 25 per cent.

Speaker.P: Before the Minister leaves that, did he notice that in the criminal legal aid the base is taken at 1965?
I referred to that.
Is it from 1965?

Yes, because it was only in 1965 that the original order was made. When I talk about distortion I am not trying to imply that any Senator or the Law Society has deliberately tried to distort but the matter is so complex that distortion is almost inevitable in the mind of anyone who is not very familiar with this particular topic. For example, arising out of what Senator Russell said, I could see the difficulty he was in. He was with me for about half of the way but he could not quite grasp some of the distinctions. Quite frankly, I do not blame him or, indeed, anyone else for that matter who found it difficult to get to the root of this.

The case has been made here that there has been no increase in the items under Schedule II since 1964, that an increase of 42 per cent is now proposed and that this is all there is to the matter. It is not as simple as that, at all. The first item under Schedule II is an “instructions” fee which is a fee at large. It covers everything and it takes every factor into account. The vast bulk of what is charged under Schedule II is charged under that item. The remaining items, which relate to specific things, are small by comparison. To give you an idea of the range of item No. 1——
It is not only the remaining items that are dealt with under the order.

I shall give an idea of the range of item No. 1, the number of things that are involved in it and the number of factors that can be taken into account in fixing a fee. It sets out seven different things and as far as I can see they cover every conceivable contingency that would be even remotely relevant.
