They are (a) the complexity, importance, difficulty, rarity, or urgency of the questions raised; (b) where money or property is involved, its amount or value; (c) the importance of the matter to the client; (d) the skill, labour and responsibility involved therein and any specialised knowledge given or applied on the part of a solicitor; (e) the number and importance of any documents perused; (f) the place where and the circumstances in which the business or any part thereof is transacted; and (g) the time reasonably expended thereon.

That general item covers the vast bulk of cases in which the question of charging under Schedule II would arise. That, as Senators will see, is completely equitable and it takes every possible relevant factor into account.
What is relevant here is that it does not come under the order.

I did not interrupt Senator O'Higgins at all. He spoke for three-quarters of an hour. I have been speaking for five minutes and he has interrupted me three times already. Item No. 1 of Schedule II which as I have said is the instructions fee has increased very considerably since 1964. Since the bulk of charging done under Schedule II comes under the instructions fee it is quite misleading to say that there has not been an increase since 1964. Of course there has been an increase and a very large one. To answer the specific point put by Senator Russell, it would be my submission to the Seanad, and I speak of my own personal knowledge without any axe to grind one way or the other, that the increase in the instructions fee allied to the increased income from conveyancing under Schedule I and the increase in legal business, including probate and administration, far outweigh the lack of progress in the specific items numbers 2 to 21, inclusive, in Schedule II of the 1970 order.
No. 21 is not included.

I am sorry. It is Nos. 2 to 20. Again this is a general item. If Senator O'Higgins has to fall back on that sort of thing it is indicative of the strength of his case. No. 21 is, in fact, the same as No. 1. To say, therefore, that because these items have not been increased since 1964 there has been no increase in remuneration, is a total and gross distortion of the facts. The instructions fee, which is the main item, has increased greatly and income from the scale fee in Schedule I has, of course, increased greatly also, because of the rise in the value of property.

Some examples of fees were given here today by Senators but unfortunately in each case they tended to pick very special types of cases. I suppose there is a natural temptation to do this but I need hardly add that they picked out the very lowest possible fees in the particular circumstances. To that extent Senators could possibly be misled as to the general scale of fees.

Perhaps a better way of giving Senators an idea of how we stand in relation to fees here would be to give a comparison with other countries. For example, in the case of a sale of unregistered land worth £10,000 the solicitors' fees here would be £400. In Northern Ireland they would be £359; in England they would be £210 and in Scotland they would be £240. I think that this is the most valid way of showing whether our fees are high or low in particular circumstances.
What was the figure?
It was £400 for unregistered land.
I do not know how the Minister got that figure. Is he sure he means unregistered?

I do. In the case of unregistered land, there are differences in the fee depending on whether the land is subject to equities. If the land is not subject to equities, which I shall not bother to explain now because it would take too long, half fee is charged and the fee referred to by Senator Nash would, of course, have been half fee. The full fee is chargeable where the land is subject to equities.

Senator O'Higgins has inquired why I did not move this motion in the Dáil. The answer to that is that it was laid on the Table of both Houses on 22nd December. It was not possible to deal with it in the Department or for me to examine it until early in January; it had to be examined, which took a week or so, and then submitted to the Government. As anyone who is familiar with the preparation and transmission of memoranda for the Government knows, it takes at least a week to get a memorandum considered by the Government. The result was that by the time I had got a Government decision on the matter the time for me to move in the Dáil had elapsed. The Dáil had by then sat for four weeks due to the fact that we came back very early this year. The only House in which it was open to me to put down this motion was this House. This is the fourth sitting week since Christmas and the last week in which I can move.

Senator O'Higgins made the statement—and I took down exactly what he said—that “This order has notthing to do with conveyancing fees” Anyone who has a copy of the General Order of 1970 on which the new Order is based, will find if he reads items 2 to 20, which are the ones with which we are concerned here, that the majority of them refer to conveyancing.
I think the Minister understands I am referring to——
Here we have Senator O'Higgins again. He makes a statement; it is wrong; it is pointed out by me to be wrong——
On a point of order, may I suggest to the Minister that I do not doubt him when he quotes my exact words, but I suggest that it must be quite clear that I was talking about conveyancing scale fees?

That is the point I am coming to. Schedule II is used for the most part in relation to conveyancing. If all the ordinary items, apart from the “instructions” fee in Schedule II, are increased by 42 per cent, there will be an immediate temptation for a solicitor not to use the scale fees in Schedule I in the case of smaller sales but to produce an itemised bill under Schedule II, as increased by the proposed order, and thereby get his total bill up to a higher figure than it would be if he had used the ordinary scale fee in Schedule I.

This, of course, will not matter in a sale of something like £10,000 because, unless it was exceptionally complicated, there would not be enough individual items to bring it up to anywhere near the scale fee which would, of course, be very high. It would matter in a sale of, say, £2,000 or £3,000 because, unless it was unusually straightforward, the Schedule II method of charging would bring it above the scale fees. This would have the effect, therefore, of increasing the conveyancing charge to the man who is buying a small house or a plot of land for £2,000 or £3,000 or £4,000, but not to the man who might be able to afford to pay higher fees in the case of a conveyance of £10,000 or £20,000. It is the small man who I would particularly like to protect because I know that people buying small properties are frequently very hard hit by the charges that are consequential on the purchase of property. I do not mean merely solicitor's fees, which are by no means the biggest item, and I want to emphasise that. There is stamp duty and very often too there are auctioneer's fees; also in some instances there are land registry fees. Between the lot, the costs that are consequential on the purchase of property amount to a figure that creates hardship for the smaller man.

MainHeading.P: One notices this particularly in relation to newly-married couples and particularly those who are getting a loan. one of the great horrors, to my mind, that faces people in that position is that when they get a loan very often they have to get a loan of the maximum amount and they are put to the pin of their collar to buy at all. They are often landed then with a bill for £50 or £100 extra that they never thought of or catered for, not for their own solicitor but for the solicitor of the building society. I think that is very unfair and what I propose to do, as soon as I can get a suitable Bill into which to put it, is to make a provision similar to what was done in 1967 in relation to lessors and lessees where the lessees had to pay the owner's costs. We prohibited that in 1967 and made is unenforceable. I propose to do the same in relation to building society solicitors' costs in order to take the burden off the unfortunate borrower who very often has not catered for it at all. Even if it means that he has to pay in the long run, and that his loan has to be increased by £50 or £100 as a result, he has 30 or 35 years, or whatever it is, to pay it back and he is not being landed with this awful problem, which I have seen so young people stuck with, of trying to many find £100 that they had never catered for, particularly when they have gone to great trouble to work out the economics of the whole thing.

Speaker.P: I do not think the Minister will find the profession against him on that.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Fitzgerald Mr. J. Fitzgerald
Speaker.P: Could I ask the Minister a question in relation to that? The Minister mentioned building society solicitors. What about local authorities?
The same principle would apply, or in the case of any lending institutions, whether it be a building society, an insurance company, a local authority or a bank.

MainHeading.P: I think I have covered at least in a general wav all the points that have been made. There have been a lot of specific fees mentioned and things of that kind. I could not follow every one of those and I cannot deal individually with them. The final point that I want to make is that I am not asking the House to choose between giving 42 per cent and giving nothing. I have already asked those concerned to put up a more reasonable figure and if they do so I would be very happy to give my blessing to it. In present circumstances and for the reasons I have given to the House today I cannot in all conscience stand over a fiaure of 42 per cent in the particular circumstances.

When I ask the House now to support me by passing this motion, it does not mean that the whole thing is nmsned and nobody gets anything. It means that we can start again and perhaps within a week or so come to an agreement on a reasonable figure. something on the lines of what Senator Miss Owens suggested. There is no question of anybody being blocked off for good if this motion is passed. It simply allows a more reasonable figure to be agreed upon and I should hope that, if this motion is passed now and this order disallowed, a reasonable figure can and will be agreed upon within the next week or two and that another order can then be made and go through without any problem.

Speaker.P: Before the Minister continues may I clarify one things I am puzzled about a figure the Mitiister gave. Am I right in thinkin- the Minister mentioned that from a sale for £10,000 in respect of unregistered land the cost is £400 here?
That is the total fees to solicitors. That is to both sides. The figure I have for other countries are for both sides also.
A client is paying only half that?
Yes. Each client is paying half.
I was afraid I was charging only half the costs.

MainHeading.Title: Private Business. - Garda Siochána Bill, 1971 : Second and Subsequent Stages.
MainHeading.P: Question proposed: “That the Bili be now read a Second Time.”

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.P: The purpose of this Bill is to enable the Government to determine the ranks of the Garda Síochána and the maximum number of members in each rank. At present the various ranks of the Garda Síochána and the maximum number in each rank are prescribed by statute, that is, by section 5 (2) of the Police Forces Amalgamation Act, 1925, and the Third Schedule to that Act, as amended by the Garda Síochána Acts of 1945 and 1962. In addition to the five Commissioners and the surgeon, the statutory maximum establishment is now 29 chief superintendents, 157 superintendents, 110 inspectors, 70 station sergeants, 1,350 sergeants and 6,000 gardaí. An increase in the statutory maximum number of inspectors and, possibly, in one or more other ranks is now required. To enable this to be done an amending Bill is required and the opportunity presented by the Bill is being availed of to amend the law so as to avoid the need, for having a special Bill passed through all its Stages in each House of the Oireachtas whenever such increases are necessary. However, the Bill does provide that any order made by the Government under the Bill will be liable to annulment by either the Dáil or the Seanad, so that each House of the Oireachtas will continue to exercise a measure of control in these matters.

MainHeading.P: As I announced in the Dáil recently the strength of the force is being increased by a further 600 gardaí, in addition to the extra 400 announced last year. This increase is in addition to recruitment to replace normal wastage and will bring the strength of the force to 7,560, the highest ever. In order to recruit the extra gardaí as quickly as possible, a recruiting campaign has been launched and I have made new appointments regulations modifying the requirements for entry to the force. The main changes in the regulations are that the minimum height for male candidates has been reduced from 5' 9” to 5' 8” and the upper age limit has been extended from 25 to 26 years. Moreover, to encourage candidates to come forward, exemption from the qualifying educational examination is being given to persons who have the leaving certificate and have passed, or have obtained grade D or better, in Irish and English. The next entrance examination is being held on 23rd March.

The increase in strength is required partly to offset the reduction in working hours in the force but mainly to help in dealing with the increased incidence of crime with which we, in common with other countries, are faced. In the year ended 30th September, 1970—the last year for which we have figures—the total number of indictable crimes was 30,756, which represents an increase of 18.4 per cent. As in previous years, about two-thirds of the total number of indictable crimes consisted of non-violent crimes against property, mainly larcenies. Most of the larcenies were from parked motor vehicles and these offences increased by over 1,800. Prosecutions were brought in respect of 44.5 per cent of the total number of indictable offences. In a further 5 per cent, the Garda were fully satisfied that they knew who was responsible but procecdings could not be taken because the person could not be found or because the evidence was inadmissible. The overall detection rate was 50 per cent as compared with 61 per cent in the previous year. In the Dublin Metropolitan Area the detection rate was 37 per cent while in the rest of the country it was 69 per cent. The increase in strength should be a substantial help in curbing the increased crime and improving the effectiveness of the protection given by the Garda Síochána to the community.

In addition to the recruitment of additional gardaí, female clerical assistants are being employed to do the office work now being done by gardaí, and 70 have already taken up duty. This policy, together with the employment of an increasing number of traffic wardens, will release a substantial number of gardaí for more important police work Other steps taken to improve the olice service to the community, include the doubling of the provision in last year's Estimates for the purchase of Garda cars and special arrangements for the rapid improvement of the Garda radio and communications system. A Garda task force has been set up in Dublin and has already proved to be very successful. I expect that there will be similar units in other areas in due course. The Garda Research and Planning Unit are at present engaged in studies designed to improve manpower utilisation and the existing arrangements for training, recruitment and promotion. In all these matters the intention is to invite the views of the Representative Bodies. A special investigation is being made of clerical procedures with a view to making them fully up-to-date and efficient. Discussions are taking place with the Department of Posts and Telegmphs with a view to providing police boxes at rural stations where this can be done without undue difficulty. These telephones will provide immediate contact throughout the 24 hours vath the local district headquarters. An accelerated programme of building Garda stations and houses, with the emphasis on system built structures, is being initiated. For this purpose I propose to set up a separate unit in my Department to deal exclusively with building projects.

From what I have said I hope Senators will accept that a sustained effort is being made in this the jubilee year of the foundation of the force to bring it to the highest attainable level of efficiency and so to equip it to carry out its task of safeguarding peace in the community and helping to protect the person and property of all our citizens. I shall continue the search for further means of introducing improvements where they appear to be necessary and I do not exclude invoking the assistance of outside experts to help the Research and Planning Unit in its task of modemising the force.
I commend the Bill to the House and ask that it be given a Second Reading.

Speaker.P: As far as I am concerned and as far as the Fine Gael Party are concerned, we approve this Bill. Many spokesmen from my party have made it clear on a number of occasions that whatever steps are required to increase the strenith, to increase the efficiency, to increase the mobility of the Garda would find ready support from us. The Minister is approaching this task, so far as this legislation goes, in the right way. In other words, he is correct in getting away from the legislation which proprovided for a particular limit to the Garda as regards the various ranks. Personally, I think it would be more satisfactory that the matter be dealt with in future on the basis proposed in this Bill, namely, that the Government will have authority from time to time to decide what is the appropriate numher or numbers in any particular rank of the Garda Síochána. They will be required to come to the Oireachtas under subsection (3) of section I of the Bill which reads:

An order under this section shall be laid before each House of the Oireachtas as soon as may be after it is made and, if a resolution annulling the order is passed by either such House within the next twenty-one days on which that House has sat after the order is laid before it, the order shall be annulled accordina,ly but without, prejudice to th e validity of anything previously done thereunder.

In other words, as regards the numbers in the Garda he is adopting the ordinary procedure whereby the order can be made increasing or fixing the number, as may be required, and that will automatically have the force of law unless it is annulled by the Houses of the Oireachtas.

MainHeading.P: As a matter of procedure, that is preferable to the system whereby the limit is set by the legislation. What worries me about the Minister's proposals is not the contents of his amending Bill but his announcement that the targets which he and, presumably, the Government have set for the increase in the Garda personnel is 1,000. That is 400 already announced and a further 600 for this year. In our present circumstances an increase of 1,000 in the Garda force does not appear to be enough. In his speech, the Minister indicated that when the numbers have been increased by the 1,000 of which he has spoken—the 600 and 400—the strength of the force will be up to 7,560. It is worth noting that no new legislation is required to bring the total of the Garda force up to that number. That is within the limits already permitted by the legislation. However, I assume—and I hope I am correct in this—that the reason for the legislation is that recruitment will not stop there. If it does stop there, I do not think it will be nearly sufficient. It was suggested on behalf of this party in the other House that a target of 2,000 should be set. I personally would have some doubts as to whether even that target would be quite sufficient. If the Minister is going to limit himself to a total of 1,000 in present-day cir cumstances that will not be sufficient.

Two of the very significant figures Inentioned by the Minister in his opening remarks related to the crime detection rate. It is a deplorable situation th-at the detection rate should show a pretty sharp decline from 61 per cent to 50 per cent all-over, particularly in the Dublin area, where the detection rate is as low as 37 per cent. Those figures, without any other arguments, would immediately justify a very con.gider,able expansion in the Garda force. Certainly a detection rate of iess than 50 per cent should not be tolerated by the people. When the situation in the Dublin area is such that the detection rate is as low as 37 per cent, it will cause alarm to Members of this House and to the public at large.

This month the Garda force has celebrated the 50th anniversary of its foundation. It is appropriate that a Bill of this sort, which enables us to look at the Garda force in depth, should be introduced this year, I wonder how many Members of the House will feel that at the end of 50 years the Garda force presents a happy picture to us. The overriding impression people will get is that for some time past the T)icture has been one of discontent. Different people may have different views as to why that is the picture that is shown to the public.

It is relevant on this occasion to see, what views are being expressed or have been expressed as to the condition of the Garda force and as to why it has reached that condition. I want to refer briefly to some extracts from three different newspapers which will give the House some indication of the kind of picture which is being presented of the Garda force so as the public Press are concerned. I refer first of all to a leading article in the Evening Herald on 29th December last. This article was dealing primarily with the remarks made by Cardinal Conway in his Christmas message but the portion relevant to this particular discussion is ithe following. In the body of the editorial it says :

It does not assist the situation. when the Government appears to shrug off civil disturbance or avoid meeting challenges to our democratic institutions. The Government has a twofold duty. It must ensure the safety of the State and see to it that the crust of the volcano remains intact.

The last is the reference to the crust of the volcano to which Cardinal Conway referred. In that short quotation I have given there is a matter of very considerable importance dealt with, that is the question of the security and safety of the State. There is no doubt at all, that to a very large extent, the security and safety of this State and the security and continuance of our parliamentary institugons depend and are going to depend on the Garda force in this country, on their training, expertise and their general efficiency. One of the dangers of allowing the Garda force either to become badly undermanned or to become in any way demoraused would be that we would face, all the sooner, a threat to our democratic institutions here.

The second article I want to refer to is an editorial in The Irish Times, of Tuesday, 28th December last. There are a number of points in this article that it would be well worth while for the Members of this House to dwell on in relation to the Garda force and in relation to the administration of justice in this country. This starts off by saying :

Quite apart from any potential threat from illegal organisations, there is certainly a general lack of cohesion, and in place a definite breakdown in co-ordination between the various parts of the justice machine in the Republic. The machine has become run-down; it needs an overhaul.
The next paragraph deals with general matters which I will not go into now. Further on in the article it says :

It would appear, too, that there has been an abandonment of one of the essential principles of the administration of justice—that it be not only efficient, but swift and thorough. This is certainly not the case at present.
It goes on to say, and this deals in particular with the Garda situation :

The breakdown can be seen at various levels. At local police level there has been a failure in investigation. A list of the number of unsolved murders would come at the head. There has been an increasing number of serious cranes, short of murder, which have not been cleared up and the Garda emergency response system (999 calls) is not up to scratch. In short, many who now seek normal civil police aid do not. apparently, get it.
I want to give two further short extracts from this. The next one is:

At national Garda level there are several problems. There appears to be an impression among the gardai that theymust observe various undefined political considerations. There isa feeling that the heads of the force have come under heaw political pressure. This not only manifests itself in poiltical offences. but also in civil and ordinarn, criminal cases.
The editorial concludes with this paragraph :

The security of the State itself depends on a police and judicial machine which not only functions smoothly and swiftly, but is seen to do so. Political activists are not the only danger to the Republic. In the ordinary way of the administration of justice, too many flaws have become apparent. A searching look at the whole machinery is one of the most urgent problems facing the Government and the people.

They are comments by two separate and distinct newspapers. Both bring out the point, which we cannot afford to overlook and is one whien I endeavoured to emphasise in a debate here a short while ago, that we may very well be in a situation where the security and safety of this State is concerned and where the continuance of our svstem of parliamentary democracy is concemed.

Of course, the searching kind of examination which one of those editorials sought was, at least to my mind, to a very great extent obtained some time ago when the Conroy Commission sat and presented its report. I think I am correct in saying it wa! !n January of 1970. The point I want to make at this stage is that the conclusions reached, as regards some matters anyhow, by the Conroy Commission justify the anxieties that have been expressed in the quotations which I have given. If Senators care to look it up they say, in paragraph 1266 of the Conroy Commission Report, page 214, that :

We would be failing in our duty to the Minister if we did not strongly urge that an examination be carried out by appropriately qualified people, into the role, organisation and personnel policy of the force and in particular, its relationship with the Department of Justice.
In the next paragraph of the Commissions Report, paragraph 1267, it goes on :

For example : (a) There was evidence of an unclear definition of roles as between the Department of Justice and the Garda Síochána. Specifically, there was a vagueness, causing uncertainty and ineffectiveness, about the relationship between the Department and the Commissioner. There seemed to us to be a lack of delegation from the Department to the force. This lack of delegation permeated the force. Authority—particularly in relation to financial resources—was not commensurate with responsibility causing an unhealthy “them and us” attitude. (b) There was no comprehensive planning based on research. No one was specifically charged with this function. The result was reaction to circumstances and ad hoc decision making. (c) There was no clear personnel policy. We found is disturbing that, in a force of this size, there was no one with specific responsibility for developing an on-going personnel policy including training and retraining.

These were conclusions reached by the Conroy Commission, a very excellent Commission. I do not-think it was the present Minister but one of his preaecessors who was responsible for its establishment, but it was a very excellent Commission which did-extremely good work and reported in a very frank way to the Minister. Those are some of the comments contained in that report. They do at least give some degree of justification for the kind of anxieties which have been expressed with regard to the force.

It is true to say that for all of its 50 years in existence the Garda force has proved itself to be not only loyal but efficient. It has proved itself to be a force which if it receives the encouragement it is entitled to receive, if the problems, difficulties and grievances which exist in it can be overcome, will be the kind of force that we have traditionally associated in the very name of the force—Garda Síochána. It has, regardless of politics—in fact, in spite of politics—proved itself to be a force which has been loyal not to particular political parties but loyal to the State. It is very important that should continue to be the position in the Garda force. I am saying that because I want to refer now to the other newspaper articles which I mentioned. I want to refer also to some remarks made by a former Minister for Justice giving his views with regard to the force as recently as October, 1971. I am not going to read out this article at length. It is headed “The Garda Revolt” and it asks: “What made 6.500 militants decide to strike?” There are a few paragraphsin this article which was as a result of investigations carried out by staff men of the Sunday Independent and reported in the Sunday Independent of 10th October last.
It stated :

Another Garda, referring to the startling statement by the Dublin Area Committee of the GRB that “armed men are robbing at will and holding the country to ransom” stated that many of the young members of the force had lost their pride in the service because of this sorry situation.

“We want the public to know that they are not getting value for their money from us but equally we want them to know that it is not our fault” he said. “The real culprits are the people at the top—they are ust not allowing us to do our duty.”
This article goes on with a comment presumably by the authors of the article :

This raises the delicate subject of veiled political interference in Garda crime-hunting, particularly in the of the spate of armed bank robberies. Most rank-and-file gardaí are firmly convinced that such interference takes place.
On the same page of the Sunday Independent of 10th October last there are some comments from the former Minister for Justice, Deputy Micheál Ó Móráin. This portion of the article sa in part:

When Mr. Ó Móráin took over as Minister for Justice in March, 1968, he found a “machine that was outmoded, outdated and inefficient”. The Organisation, he said “belonged to the horse and buggy days at every level.”
He goes on :

“I immediately acceded to the Garda Representative Body's request to establish the Conroy Commission. I did this because I was utterly dissatisfied with the lack of efficiency I found in the force.” The Commission, he said did a “fairly good job” but he felt its implementation was “rather sluggish”. “The vital parts in the report should have been dealt with in a very urgent way,” he said.
Later on—this is the last quotation I propose giving—he is reported, as saying :
In his belief, morale in the force was now lower than ever. “There was some excuse before Conroy, now there is no excuse.”
Those are comments made by the Minister's predecessor in office.

Speaker.P: They are selective quotations.
I am prepared to read the entire article if the Minister wishes. I do not think they are in any way selective. We might as well keep the Minister right. This starts:

A complete revision of the Garda code book, the 735 page volume of a Garda's do's and don'ts, was suggested by the former Minister for Justice, Mr. Micheál Ó Móráin, when we talked to him. Mr. Ó Móráin said it was a matter of urgency in the present circumstances to alter the provision in the code which enables the Garda Commissioner to fire a Garda single-handed without appeal. “But this is only one of the alterations I would like to make,” he said. “The Conroy Commission recommended a whole series of changes which have not yet been put into effect.” He attacked the “rob at will” statement from the Dublin Area Committee of the GRB.” I am completely amazed at this queer statement and like Mr. O'Malley, I would want to know what it was all about if I were Minister” he said:

“If the men who made the statement have knowledge which could legally bring a criminal to trial, and they have failed to do this, then they themselves should be disciplined or flung out of the force.”

I have read the next bit of the statement which was referring to the appointment of the Conroy Commission and his reference to the vital part of the report should have been dealt with in a very urgent way. It then states:

MainHeading.P: He added that, in his personal view, he was very dissatisfied with the present training system. “I am appalled at the number of nuts being released to the public.”
These are some things I left out from the quotations I was giving. The quotation continues:

“I am amazed that so many of them are left in the force for so long. I feel that a great deal more care should be taken in selecting recruits at the application stage. After all, the longer they remain in the force, the harder they find it to adapt to another way of life. I believe the unsuitable ones should be weeded out at the Templemore stage.” He was highly critical of the methods used to select sergeants. “We are being very badly served by the present system,” he said. “I made some minor changes myself but I think it is still not satisfactory. I would establish a special Sergeants Corps and send them abroad for training.”

“Another thing which is seriously wrong with the system is of sending young rookies to the city immediately after leaving Templemore. They are often under the control of old lags who are more concerned with dodging the column than anything else. They learn all the bad habits a sergeant can teach them.”
Then I quoted the next bit and his belief that morale in the force was now lower than ever. “There was some excuse before Conroy, now there is no excuse”. It finishes:
The serious under-manning in the force had created the situation where a garda, in certain parts of Dublin city at night, was as “rare as a Red Indian on the banks of the Potomac”.

That is the entire article. I am not in any way being selective in the quotations I gave. In fact, I left out some of the bits which might cause the Minister some sore toes if they were trodden on. Those are comments by the Minister's predecessor as recently as four months ago, and quotations from an article made following an investigation into what was described as “The Garda Revolt”.

I am not reading out these quotations for the sake of condemning the Garda force. I have the very greatest admiration for the Garda Síochána and I have never made any secret of that. I am concerned when I see this kind of picture emerging in public, when I see the kind of picture shown in the articles I have quoted—the comments by the Minister's predecessor and the two newspaper leading articles and, in addition, the section of the Conroy Commission which I quoted. On top of that we have the figures which the Minister mentioned here himself this evening with regard to the number of crimes and with regard to the decline in the detection rate.

I do not believe the situation is beyond saving and I think in one way the entire relevancy of all these grievances is directly to the question of the undermanning of the Garda force. The Minister, I think, referred to the question of retirements and reduced working hours and that kind of thing. I think it is correct to say that not only have working hours in the force been reduced but that duties have been increased. On top of that you have the ordinary retirements on age grounds. You have, naturally, the question of wastage arising by deaths of members of the force and you have further the question of resignations.

I do not know whether my information is entirely accurate in this, but I think I am correct in saying that if you grouped sergeants, gardaí and recruit gardaí together over the last five years the resignations were probably in the region of something over 200. But 200 is a substantial figure in relation to the total which the Minister now proposes raising. It is just one-fifth of the figure the Minister proposes increasing the force by. I think the figure was about 250. You must take into account the reduction in working hours, and that in a force of about 7,000 it would be normal at any one time to have possibly up to 400 or 500 on leave.

When you deduct from the total the personnel who would be assigned barrack duties, barrack orderlies or clerks, and when you make allowance also for the proportion which at any given time would be on rest, it would seem to me that if we are thinking in terms of a total of about 7,000 gardaí at the moment, the effective strength of the force at any given time would probably not exceed about 4,000; that is the effective strength of people who would be available for duty outside of barrack duty.

If those kinds of calculations are anywhere nearly correct I think we can get some kind of idea of the immensity of the task which at present —and, I would suggest, for some time past—has been imposed on our Garda force. I attribute, rightly or wrongly, any apparent trouble and discontent in the force to the fact that the force has been undermanned, to the fact that there are additional duties to be performed and that simply there are not enough men there to do the work that has to be done in the manner that they would like to do it.

What are the consequences when you have a serious degree of under-manning in the Garda? I think it was because there were not sufficient gardaí available to be called on that the British Embassy was burned. I saw, as others did, the television pictures of that event. Like everyone else in this House I deplored what happened. I saw the televised pictures of what seemed to be a mass of people. I do not know what proportion of them were actively involved in the wanton destruction of the British Embassy but it seemed quite clear to me that unfortunately the picture which went abroad was that whatever gardaí were available were not sufficiently numerous to prevent the wanton destruction which took place.

All of us know the consequences to this country of that single event. We have read of the effect on tourism, the cancellation of conferences, even the cancellation of the international rugby match with Scotland. These are all attributed, if not solely certainly largely, to that event. I feel that if the Commissioner of the Garda and if the Garda administration had more forces at their command and more forces trained in riot and mob control, that sorry spectacle could have been prevented.

What are the other kinds of consequences we face if the Garda force are undermanned? For some time past I and many others in my party and in the Minister's party have been concerned by the apparently flourishing and growing state of unlawful organisations in this part of the country. The Minister seems to be taking fairly strong action at the moment and credit should be given to him for this, but a lot of water has passed under the bridge since these unlawful organisations are coming more and more on the public scene in this part of the country. I do not think that could have happened if the Garda force were of sufficient strength, or if they had the kind of training referred to in the Conroy Commission Report, that is, the policy with regard to the role and functions of the Garda and a personnel policy. If specialised training had been given to particular sections of the Garda we would not have witnessed a situation where not merely this island but our neighbouring island could be shocked and stunned by what happened in Aldershot and where a claim could be made from an illegal organisation apparently based in this city that they were taking responsibility.

If the Garda force had been of sufficient strength in the past few years, we would not have witnessed the parades in para-military type uniforms, the firing of volleys at funerals, the giving of Press conferences in this city of the type which have been given. I am not blaming the Garda force nor suggesting that they sat down on the job. I would be loth to blame the Minister, as all of us are to blame to some extent. We should have insisted in time that a dramatic expansion of the Garda and the Army should have taken place.

I am justified in saying that members of my party were alert to the danger possibly before others and that we made our views known and made it clear there would be no withholding of support on our part if the necessary action were taken by the Government. I am glad that action is now being taken. What is concerned in an expansion of the Garda, though very important, is not merely the question of the prevention or detection of crime and the arrest of criminals in the ordinary sense, but we may well be concerned with the security of this State. If laws made by the Oireachtas are flouted, then parliamentary democracy is in danger and laws made by the Oireachtas may be flouted and will be flouted if we have not a sufficiently strong force of gardaí properly trained and efficient enough in the performance of their duty to ensure that the laws of the only law-making authority in this State are enforced within the State.

In recent years in this part of the country there has been, as in most other countries, a considerable degree of mob action. Mob action can lead to the kind of spectacle I spoke of when speaking on the burning of the British Embassy. It can lead to other undesirable events and it has got to be firmly controlled by a Garda force of sufficient strength to be able to undertake mob control and riot control with confidence. These are the problems faced by the modern Garda force. To a large extent they are problems associated mainly with the larger urban areas and cities. Essentially, it is the kind of thing that runs right through a country both in urban and rural areas.

The last thought I wish to leave with the Minister is that there should be a rethink on the part of the Department about the closing down of rural Garda barracks. I take the view and I have maintained it for a long time that it is a mistake to argue in favour of the closing of small rural Garda stations on the grounds that because there is an absence of crime in an area no Garda station is required. That is looking at the thing the wrong way around. We should rather ask ourselves the question: is it not because of the existence of the small Garda station, whether a one-man or two-man station, in a particular rural area that there has been an absence of crime in that area? In the long run I do not think we serve the interests of the people of rural Ireland well by closing these small stations on the grounds that there has not been any serious crime in the area.

I should like to see the Department thinking again about that. The old village garda did a great deal for the people of rural Ireland. He was a person who secured the confidence of the people, who was very much in the know in the community. Because he was in the know and because he had the confidence of people in various parts of rural Ireland, the law was kept, the law was administered and there was no serious crime. We would be doing a good day's work for rural Ireland if we tried to get back to some extent to that situation.

It is not the same thing to send a garda through an area on patrol on a motor cycle or a Garda squad car. That is quite impersonal. It has not got the same effect. There is no question of gathering the confidence of the people of the locality. They are unknown to the garda in the squad car. If the Minister was prepared to rethink on this question he will get the opportunity of doing so provided the Garda force are now expanded sufficiently so as to permit of the continuance of small rural Garda stations as well as providing sufficient strength in the Garda force, particularly in Dublin city, but also in a very special way in the other cities and urban areas.

Speaker.P: I welcome the Bill and go a long way with the comments of Senator O'Higgins. I have the highest regard for the Garda force. I am amazed that the Garda force, particularly in smaller urban areas and in the rural areas, are drawn almost drum tight. We have a small number of gardaí trying to do what probably three times as many did heretofore. It amazes me because, whether it is a small urban or rural area, there are recurrences of various types of crimes. It is greatly to their credit that with the small number of gardaí available for investigation and for the many other duties they have to perform, they are so successful in apprehending the people involved. In certain cases they do not get very much cooperation from the people. It is not their fault, but I should like to say that the Garda force are held in the highest possible esteem by the general public.

The question of what the size of the Garda force should be is another matter. Regarding recruitment to the Garda, I understand that the practice is to recruit gardaí at the age of 18 years. A youth of 18 years is only a boy. The training they get is of very short duration. Very often, because of pressure and because of the need to get them on to the streets and on patrol, these young gardaí are semi-trained when they leave the depot at Templemore. They are then sent to bigger depots or barracks where they are supposed to undergo training in street patrols and the various other duties carried out there. I am told that sometimes they only have six months training in Templemore before they are assigned to one of those stations. It is much too soon to send out any young lad and expect him to undertake the onerous duties the average garda has to deal with.

A garda's duties requires patience, perseverence and a very cool head. If a young fellow gets himself into any hot spot, particularly where there is any rough and tumble business going on, it is quite likely that his youthfulness might overcome his sensibility. Sometimes they get involved in incidents for which they have to take the blame afterwards. I ascribe a lot of the trouble which some of these young gardaí get into to the inadequate training they receive and to their being asked at a very young age to undertake duties for which they are not fitted.

MainHeading.P: I should prefer to see a different system of recruitment. If it is decided to recruit them at 18 years of age they should at least be required to do one year's cadetship which would take place at the recruiting depot and that they would not be allowed out until they had finished a complete year's training. In that way they would be reasonably fitted to undertake the duties of a garda. They cannot anticipate what will happen. They just have to attend to problems as they meet them. It is asking too much to put a young man of 18 or 19 years into an area where there is a lot of strain and tension and to expect him to behave like a man of 35 years of age.

Senator O'Higgins mentioned the difficulty of having an insufficient number of gardaí for patrols and street duties. The Garda force at the moment are being used as a para-military force because of the conditions that appertain where large numbers of gardaí have to be held in a position of readiness for despatch at very short notice to restrain mob actions. In this way the beats and the small stations down the country have to be denuded to allow their complements to be brought to areas where there is greater need for them.

For that reason I agree with Senator O'Higgins when he said that an increase of 600 will not be sufficient. With shorter working hours and the more onerous duties the Garda are expected to perform nowadays, they are more comparable to an army force than a police force. They often have to stand by in their hundreds to deal with situations which in my opinion should be dealt with by the military force.

Riot control duties are a very dangerous task for a Garda force. They are an unarmed force and their only method of defence is their batons. I listened attentively to Senator O'Higgins when he quoted some articles from the newspapers. The people who write those articles tell us about the deficiencies that exist in the force, why there is dissatisfaction among the members and the steps that should be taken to remedy them. If a body of gardaí who are sent out on riot control use their batons when attacked by a mob, the newspapers the following day will accuse them of police brutality. If the gardaí are to do their duty they have to be allowed to control the situation in which ever way they think best. If they are subjected to an attack from a mob and they cannot restrain the mob because of their lack of numbers, surely they are entitled to defend themselves. Last year when we had a lot of mob rioting around Dublin the newspapers the following day carried headlines of police brutality.

We must have confidence in the Garda Síochána if they are to carry out their duties in a proper manner. I am satisfied that they are a most disciplined force. I have never seen a garda use more force than was necessary in the execution of his duty but we must recognise that the necessity to use extra force sometimes arises. The Garda are the only people who stand between mob law and the rule of law and order. They are there on the authority of the Oireachtas and they deserve the support of the people.

I was glad to hear the Minister say that clerical duties heretofore carried out by members of the Garda will now be undertaken by clerical assistants. It is high time this was done. A great number of gardaí have been tied up with clerical duties in barracks for years. They are men who could make a very considerable contribution to law enforcement.

The Bill will increase the number of men in the Garda force. Whether this increase will prove sufficient remains to be seen, but the Minister has power to make further increases if he so desires. It is most important, and it cannot be overemphasised, that the gardaí are the custodians of the peace. They are the people who will ensure that the laws passed in the Houses of the Oireachtas will be complied with and respected. The Minister should be encouraged to increase the number of men by approximately 1,000 instead of 600. The laws are being flouted daily and the authority of the Oireachtas is slowly passing away for want of a strong Garda force who will ensure the enforcement of the laws that are passed here. If we cannot ensure that the laws are strictly enforced we should not waste our time passing such laws.

Speaker.P: I am in general agreement with what the Minister is trying to achieve in this Bill. Like the last speaker, I wonder if the Minister is going far enough in the proposed increase in the numbers of the Garda force. In recent advertisements on television we were told that 800 new recruits are being sought. Let me pay a compliment to the Garda Síochána: nobody doubts their ability and, in general, they are as good a police force as can be found anywhere in the world, but they are suffering at present from a lack of sufficient numbers. In my view, and the Minister adverted to this at the weekend, they have to deal with people who certain judicial officials allow out on bail and who in turn commit certain crimes while out on bail. This necessitates and creates far more work than can be handled by our present force of gardaí. Gardaí who apprehend people for the commission of crimes must find it extremely disheartening that those people are allowed out on bail on sureties which, at the present rate of inflation, are only nominal.

The whole concept of bail should be approached in a different way. I do not suggest that one arm of the Legislature should be interfered with but I am sure the question of bail could be dealt with without undue interference. Bail should be related in a more realistic manner to the present value of money. Many years ago bail might have helped to stop various people from committing criminal offences. It might in effect stop various people from committing crime. The higher bail would be, surely the less chance they would have of getting that bail. It would confirm in the minds of the Garda that what they were doing was right and would allay the frustrations they experience at present in the apprehension of these criminals.
Some gardaí ask: “What is the point of catching people at present? What is the point of arraigning them in court, when they can get off so lightly and on such light bail?”

I have not gone into depth on the grievances of the gardaí. They have been aired at a meeting they held in Mitchelstown. The Minister, in his reply, might give us the reasons why it was ever necessary that a certain section of the gardaí should hold such a meeting in Mitchelstown. I do not know the reason. I should like to be told here and one of the Houses of the Oireachtas is the right place in which to give that reason.

MainHeading.P: Senator O'Higgins referred also to the Minister's statement, a copy of which was circulated. He mentioned one point with which I agree. Other people, including Senator Honan, I think, also referred to it. On page 2 it states:
In addition to the recruitment of additional gardaí, female clerical assistants are being employed to do the office work now being done by gardaí, and 70 have already taken up duty.

One would have thought that clerical work would have been done by people like this long ago, instead of using gardaí, who should be either out on the beat or in a patrol car, or apprehending criminals. That is the work they should have been doing rather than paper work and office work in the Garda station. This does not mean that some gardaí must not stay in the stations.

I should like also to refer to another statement made by the Minister, with which I agree, and that is in regard to the equipment in patrol cars at present. It is absolutely essential that we keep the gardaí equipped with all the modern gadgets necessary to catch and apprehend criminals.

I am going to make a statement that may not be to the liking of many people and it is this: if some years ago powers had been given, either to the courts or to the gardaí, for dealing with certain matters, there would not be the necessity today to employ so many gardaí and to have the furoré that is going on around the country at the moment. My own opinion is that this question was not tackled in time. Three or four years ago was the proper time to stop crime.

Now I should like to advert to a few things that might not be so general. Up to recently it was stated that certain Garda stations throughout the country were to be closed. If new gardaí are to be recruited, will the Minister give us an undertaking that the stations that it had been intended to close will now remain open? I would be satisfied if he gave a general statement. It may be that in certain circumstances one or two stations may of necessity have to be closed. Surely, if we are going to recruit all the gardaí we are looking for at present, some of the stations threatened with closure must at least be kept open.

The question of siting the Garda Training Centre in Templemore is one I have been dubious about from the beginning. We had sufficient buildings throughout Ireland without erecting a new one, at State cost, in Templemore. I believe that such a building could have been found that would have served adequately the training facilities necessary for new gardaí entering the force. It was an unnecessary expense.

Finally, I should like to refer to my own area of Dún Laoghaire-Rathdown, and I am sure Senator Keery will bear me out in what I have to say. Of all the Garda stations in Dún Laoghaire-Rathdown, probably the only one that is fully and properly manned is Dún Laoghaire itself. The substations, such as Dalkey, Kill o' the Grange, and so on, are not properly manned at present.

Another aspect of places like Dún Laoghaire is that they are being continuously built up. It will be necessary to provide these new areas with Garda stations. With the outflow of population on all sides of the city there is an urgent necessity for additional stations. I should like the Minister to comment on all of these points.

I do not think this Bill which has come too late goes far enough in providing what I have suggested should be provided in it. It is a Bill, like many other Bills, that is closing the stable door after the horse has bolted. It has been delayed too long. Power should have been given to the Garda long ago to enable them to prevent crime.

Speaker.P: I should like to join with Senators in saying a few words in support of this Bill. Certainly it is a matter of great importance that the Garda force should be strengthened. Apart from numbers and matters such as equipment and the condition of Garda stations, which have all been adequately covered in the debate, I should like to touch on some other items which would help the gardaí to perform more tolerably their extremely difficult and unenviable task—a task which in my experience they perform with considerable efficiency and with a great deal of cheerfulness and courtesy. One of the striking facts about a policeman in our society is his value, quite apart from his day-to-day duties. In many communities he is a much respected figure; a man who, while off duty, may well be making a major contribution to the local community through his own personal interest in youth clubs and other work. This contribution to our country is acknowledged all too seldom. Often the only time people notice the gardaí is when they come in contact with them for some minor offence or other, maybe a traffic offence. It is a pity that it is that type of contact which tends to build up the most common, or the most often expressed, image of the police.

MainHeading.P: On this point of public contact with the police force I should like to stress how important it is that all our citizens should co-operate as fully as possible with the force in the important work which they are doing for the community. It may be because of our history but I very much regret at times that people are loath to refer matters of suspicion to the police or to draw the attention of the police to strange occurrences. People seem to prefer either to pass by on the other side or to have a misguided sympathy for the person to whom they would draw the attention of the police. The co-operation and interest of every citizen in the work of the police force is of very great importance. After all, prevention of crime is a major part of the duty of the police. I understand in many cases when police are investigating reports of various kinds, or if their attention is drawn to something which a citizen feels is a matter of legitimate suspicion or concern, that even if that particular call or report happens to be either a wild goose chase or something of no sinister significance, it may well lead to some criminal being captured unawares or start off a chain of detection, completely unrelated to the initial complaint, which might be of major value to the community. It is extremely important, particularly at the moment when our Garda numbers are tightly stretched, that citizens should in this way feel that they can contribute to the maintenance of law and order and decent living conditions in our community by co-operating with the gardaí through the reporting of suspicious activities and in assisting them in any way they can in carrying out their duties.

May I say in this context too, that there are other institutions in our society which can help the gardaí enormously in their work. We should not look at the work of the Garda force in isolation. For example, in some cases, if the actual procedure of a garda going about his duty is treated in isolation, particularly, say, when dealing with matters of delinquency among young people, or matters of vandalism, if the legal process is not properly handled and if a garda is not given proper support, there is always the danger that the straight forward business of a garda may well create a long-term future criminal rather than simply dealing with an immediate situation. It is extremely important that if a garda is pursuing a case, particularly where young people are concerned, that there should, wherever possible, be a full back-up from services of a probationary nature or from the State's social services because in many cases there is a social explanation for what has happened. It is important, therefore, that if there is a problem of a non-legal nature this should be dealt with when it is brought to light through some criminal activity detected and dealt with by the Garda.

In the same way too, the work of the Garda would be facilitated greatly if the people responsible for the punishments meted out to criminals who are brought before our courts and sentenced as a result of Garda activity, co-operated with the Garda. It is important that inside our prisons, and particularly inside places of detention for young delinquents, that the work of the Garda in detecting criminal offences in the first instance, should not be set at naught by any system which could turn these young offenders into long-term criminals.

That is why it is so important that our detention systems and our various punishments should be primarily aimed at rehabilitating the young delinquent. Otherwise the gardaí may find that the young person who they at first detain on a relatively minor offence becomes a life-time criminal, a familiar face they find themselves chasing indefinitely. In the same way it is very important that our court procedures—this is, of course, something we have discussed on other legislation—should be speeded up and, indeed, if additional staff is required for the administration of justice on the legal side, it should be realised that this is in many ways of equal importance with the additional recruitment of gardaí.

Again, if the system of administration of justice is slow and cumbersome that means that gardaí will find themselves wasting many hours sitting around in courts, waiting for their cases to be heard and, again, particularly if for whatever reason, they find that a great number of their cases are unsuccessful they tend to get very dispirited and disillusioned. That is a most unfortunate occurrence because after all it is important that anyone who is doing the sort of important work for the community that the Garda force are doing should be helped to maintain the constructive attitude towards their work with which I am sure all new recruits to the force begin.

One particular danger I should like to refer to is that if at any stage—this can happen particularly in dealing with the young thugs that, alas, one can find all too frequently these days in a city like Dublin—gardaí may be tempted from time to time to take the law into their own hands because they may think that if they are attacked on some occasion their only answer is to hit back, this is a temptation that must be resisted at all costs.

There have been references to the scenes outside the British Embassy recently. I do not know if the speakers who referred to that were asking for stronger action by the Garda on that occasion, but my own view is that the activity of the Garda on that occasion was quite remarkable. It was their presence in holding the line despite the odds and despite the threats from the fire bombs to themselves as much as to the building that prevented that occasion becoming what it could have been. In addition to this most unfortunate burning, there could have been a very serious riot situation in the city which could well have escalated. I certainly would like to share in the tribute which the Minister for Justice made at that time to the gardaí who were on duty there.

Speaker.P: I should not like my views to be misunderstood. What I said in relation to that was in no way intended to be critical of the performance of the gardaí. It was simply that in my opinion if you had a sufficient number there could be more gardaí available but I certainly do not criticise in the slightest those who were on duty.

I will let the Senator's two statements stay on the record. I do not wish to comment further on them. The point I was making was that on that occasion and, indeed, on many other occasions the gardaí showed tremendous restraint, tremendous discipline, tremendous control. That is extremely important because if at any time a garda would do something as foolish and misguided as taking the law into his own hands he would create a situation which might well lead to the undermining of the whole system of law and order and respect for the police in our society. It is on the very occasion on which that sort of thing happens that some particular person, and often those entirely in the wrong, making use of the machinery which is always there to protect the abused citizen, can set about prosecuting the garda or can set about this business of harassing the garda and raising the old immediate scare of police brutality. In this way by creating headline news they can help to undermine the reputation and image of the police force. For that reason I would like to stress the importance of the discipline and restraint of the Garda force of which we are all justly proud.

MainHeading.P: I should like to welcome, as others have welcomed, the handing over of many of the clerical duties of the Garda force to proper clerical staff. That should be an important easing of the burden on the ordinary patrolmen. On this point I should like to refer to another possible field of recruitment to the Garda Síochána to which I have not seen any reference and I do not know if there is any forward thinking on this particular matter: I do not think we have at the moment in Ireland any recruitment of university graduates into the police force although quite a few of our Gardaí do take university degrees through evening courses while working as members of the force. But I understand that in many other countries there is an organised pattern for the recruitment of university graduates to the police force. May I say it is not recruitment in any particularly high level or anything of that kind? In fact, university graduates who enter police forces in other countries do their stint on the beat and that is how they begin. But the idea behind the recruitment of graduates, apart from its recognition that being a policeman is in fact a vocation which one can find in people with all sorts of educational background and interest, it is also a recognition that the graduate can in his future development in the police force make a major contribution to the force if he proves to be a talented policeman by the application of the academic discipline and training which he has received during his university career. This may well be important in the future as unfortunately our criminal classes together with the general body politic seem to be getting cleverer and more sophisticated every day of the week. It is important that our gardaí should also be prepared for this and that their skills, techniques and abilities should match, step for step and, indeed, keep ahead of anything the criminal may be able to devise.

I should like to stress the importance—I am speaking now without a great deal of knowledge of what is being done in our police force on this —of ensuring that our police force keep constantly abreast of all sorts of new techniques of crime prevention and detection which science may devise, which initially may be put into use in economies more developed than ours because of the greater scientific research facilities available.

Apart from scientific techniques, not so much here in Ireland as in the United States and elsewhere, police forces now seem to be paying more and more attention to the research work and study which take place in the field of social science and social studies. There are many people who, when they hear anyone talking about psychiatry, psychology or social work in connection with law and order, feel like reaching for the gun and saying this is just soft liberalism. I think that social scientists and researchers have made a major contribution to the understanding of crime and of patterns of crime, particularly in the United States where they have very serious ghetto problems. In many major cities in the United States they have had “no-go” areas such as we now see in the Six Counties. They have had “no-go” areas in the major cities of the United States for a very long time. They have a great deal of understanding of how this serious situation comes about and I think now they have a great deal of understanding of how one can prevent the creation of “no-go” areas in urban ghettoes.

I do not know if we have anything in Dublin yet that one could rightly describe in the same way as a ghetto, but we have some very tough areas which have very severe social problems and which pose a menace to law and order in the community. I think it is the job for social research, research of the social services. Indeed, it is a question of the Garda perhaps being able to use these services and research as an ally to try to make sure that such areas do not become established as “no-go” areas and that, if there has been any tendency in this direction, major steps should be taken to prevent this going any further. In this respect—I am afraid I have not got the reference in front of me—but recently I think there was a study of one particularly tough area in Dublin published in the Economic and Social Review which is published by the Economic and Social Research Institute, which dealt in a very enlightened way with the sort of behaviour pattern in that area. There was much there on which our police force could act and plan for the future.

One of the frightening things about this study of a particularly bad and underprivileged area in Dublin city was that it read to me like a description of the sort of situation with which we are becoming only too familiar every day in Belfast, where they are in a quite different, emergency and virtually war situation.

Speaker.P: I welcome this Bill in this present crisis period. I think it is most important that the Garda force be strong enough to deal with any emergencies that may arise. I am not quite sure if the provisions that are at present being made will make it strong enough, but any measures that can be taken to strengthen the force are welcome and I am sure we shall all approve heartily of them. I should like to echo Senator Keery's plea for the building up of the technical side of the Garda force, the scientific side, by the employment of graduates. If you are going to keep abreast of the criminals you have got to have the latest know-how, you have got to have the latest expertise and you have got to have people who are capable of dealing with unusual situations and unusual problems, and I think we will need graduates in the force. These will be graduates who have been through the mill, who have trained on the beat and who have the particular technical knowledge or the particular expertise in some field or other which will make our force more efficient and more able to deal with the modern criminal.

MainHeading.P: I should like to refer to some consequences of the Conroy Report, and let us remember that the Conroy Commission sat because of pressure from the Garda themselves. This pressure was exerted mainly by the rank and file of the force. As a direct consequence of this the reforms which Conroy suggested mainly dealt with the grievances of the rank and file of the force. These reforms were welcome. They did a tremendous amount to overcome the dissatisfaction which the younger gardaí had. I think that Conroy did a very valuable job. However, there are some problems which have resulted from that report and from the implementation of its recommendations.

One problem, for example, is the problem of overtime. This is all very well, and I personally feel that the Conroy Report was quite right in saying that there should be a fixed time and beyond that time gardaí get overtime. When it comes to calculating the overtime and working out the number of hours that a particular garda has done over his normal course of duty, then applying to the Department of Justice for the extra money, then the correspondence involved, this takes up a tremendous amount of valuable working hours of, say, a superintendent in a country area. These jobs should be done by administrative staff. I have spoken to superintendents about this and they say that it takes up to two months to get these overtime claims sorted out between the particular superintendents and the Department of Justice. This means a great deal of correspondence; it means superintendents in a country area must do a great deal of work which quite obviously they should not be doing. The super-intendent's main job is to go out and ensure that law and order is being maintained and his job is not to send in overtime claim forms for members of the force and to spend up to two months corresponding with the Department of Justice.

I should like the Minister to look into the problem of streamlining the overtime claims. I would ask him to take them out of the hands of the superintendents altogether, that is, the superintendents in the smaller areas where they do not have any clerical assistance. I think it is quite wrong that a superintendent should be doing this. The Conroy Report came about because of pressure from the younger members of the force and it reflects this very accurately : while it dealt with the problems at the bottom it did not deal with the many problems at the top that need to be tackled.

Let me try to illustrate this. I live in two places, not one. I live in Dublin some of the time and I live in East Cork the rest of the time. The area in which I live in Dublin is under the jurisdiction of the superintendent in Pearse Street. He is an ordinary superintendent with 407 men under his control. Under his control comes this Parliament building, the British Embassy, and the other Departmental buildings, the hub, really, of much of the nation's life. It is too much of a responsibility for one man and there are various ways of dealing with the problem as it stands. I have dealings with the Garda in Pearse Street through my residence in Trinity College. I have always found them extremely pleasant and efficient and ready to help and understand the problems we had in the college, but they have a big area to cover and it seems too much for one superintendent to be in charge of 407 men and be responsible for an area which comprises the most important buildings in the State. Something should be done to deal with this situation.

In the other area in which I live, East Cork, the superintendent has other problems. He has a big area to cover. He has basically the problem of mobility and the problem of communications. I am pleased to see in the Minister's speech, of which I am fortunate enough to have a copy, that he speaks about the Garda Research and Planning Unit being engaged in studies designed to improve manpower utilisation and the existing arrangements for training, recruitment and promotion and also the problems of the purchase of Garda cars and special arrangements for the rapid improvement of the Garda radio and communications. There is no doubt that we need to be technically equipped in the area of communications, and as well as applying to urban areas this applies especially to the rural areas where there are large areas to cover and there must be proper radios and a proper link system with the central area.

The Minister is well aware of this particular problem and I would urge him to deal with it in one aspect by forming bigger centres and by the employment of a more mobile force operating from these larger centres. This may mean closing down some of the smaller substations. This has already been done but use may have to be made of these substations on one or two days per week and the main force will operate from the big centre with a very mobile car fleet and a good system of radio communications operating from the central spot. This is one of the key ways of utilising manpower and of getting the best coverage in a particular area.

I have also heard of situations in which the Garda cars are not turned in until they have clocked up 120,000 miles. A Garda car which has clocked up 100,000 miles will not make much of an effort to check traffic or people who commit speeding offences or people who have committed a more serious crime and are intent on getting away in a modern car. If we do not change our Garda cars more often, we cannot hope to have a chance of catching the more efficient modern criminal.

As the Minister is aware people tend to commit crimes nowadays by impersonating the force and we had a very spectacular one in our area in East Cork recently when a creamery lorry was stopped by supposed members of the Garda and the creamery lorry happened to be carrying a large sum of money, the takings from various farmers. The man in the lorry got out and was promptly hit over the head by the “superintendent of the Garda” and bundled behind a ditch, and somebody made off with the loot.

In a political situation impersonation could cause all kinds of untold repercussions. It is a problem which should be brought before the Minister and the Department should bear this in mind when thinking about the tactics of the modern criminal. This backs up the case made by Senator Keery for a really expert research group inside the Garda administration to be one step ahead of the criminal in his use of technical innovations and scientific methods.

In my experience some more imagination could be used in the decoration and fitting out of the stations in which the gardaí have to live and work and interview the public. It is common to have tintawn carpets on concrete floors, which is not a very comfortable existence. It is also common to have bare boards in the offices in which the gardaí have to interview members of the public, and this does not create a good image either. No station which I was in during recent weeks shows a sign of any taste in colour schemes, redecoration or choice of furniture. While one does not expect the interior of a station in East Cork to look like the American Embassy fitted out with plastic G.Is in the corner, a bit of taste exercised by the Board or Works or whoever redecorates and fits out the Garda stations could do a great deal for the psychological attitude not only of the members of the force but of the people who go in to check on their gun licences or interview the station superintendent in the normal course of events. I would urge that a more imaginative attitude be adopted towards doing the smaller things, because often these smaller things can make a terrific difference.

I have covered most of the points that I wished to make. Basically we will have to increase the strength of our force in the urban areas where the crime is at its highest and decrease the strength in rural areas.
