To make up for the decrease in rural areas we must increase our mobility and we do this by improving the standard of the cars and radios, getting good cars and getting the people together in the main centres, working from the centre outwards and generally giving a good coverage.

The problems in urban areas need much study. The sociological studies suggested by Senator Keery can be a great help and they can help us to understand what makes a criminal in a new housing area like Ballyfermot or what motivates someone towards crime in an older and more run-down area in the centre of the city. This will help the Garda in their detection and should generally protect the citizens who are permanently at risk. With these suggestions I welcome this Bill.

Speaker.P: I should like to express my welcome and appreciation of this very useful Bill. While we can criticise it and say it is long overdue the timing is right to re-equip, re-organise and strengthen the Garda force. I do not believe it is necessary because of current affairs. We had a deplorable situation throughout the country and I disagreed with the policy of closing down stations at a time when centralisation was taking place. The Garda force are desperately overstretched. They have to control an ever-increasing toll of vandalism throughout the country.

I regret I cannot agree with Senator West in saying that we should cut down on the Garda force in the rural areas and strengthen them in urban or city areas. While I appreciate that there is very extensive and highly valued property in the city, at the same time with a superintendent, sergeants and gardaí the whole area can be covered inside 15 minutes. If I may refer to my own country in Donegal we had, prior to the current events, a situation in which was nearly impossible for the members of the Garda force involved to work. We had an area from Donegal town, Ballybofey——
Finn Valley.

Yes. I thank the Senator. We had an area from Ballybofey, Castlefin, Convoy, Raphoe, Lifford, St. Johnstown, Carrigan to Bridge End, a distance of 60 miles, to cover and those stations closed at 6 o'clock. They had one central station and there was a notice on the station door to ring Letterkenny in the event of the gardaí being needed. This is an impossible task for the gardaí. You could drive from Buncrana right through Donegal and be undetected. I hope the new approach to the strengthening of the Garda force will alleviate the position and that we will never have a return to that situation.

MainHeading.P: I also support the proposals to modernise the equipment to be used by the gardaí. Emphasis should be laid on the type of radio equipment the gardaí will use. One of the popular things to do now is buy a transistor and get it tuned into the gardaí. The Minister and his Department should look into this aspect of the gardaí's equipment. I should like to see the Garda manpower strengthened. They should be very well equipped and paid as much as the State can afford, to make it an attractive job and encourage men to join. I hope the Minister will continue to increase the strength of the gardaí to look after the country, to prevent rather than cure. There are areas in which vandalism is practically out of control. I welcome the Bill and support it fully. I hope we will have a further improvement as the State funds can afford it.

Speaker.P: Most of what I wished to say has been said and I have no wish to repeat it. First of all, I should like to join the other Senators in welcoming the Bill. The Minister has shown an awareness of the need to improve the force, improve the numbers first of all and the facilities they have, to bring it up to the required standards compatible with a modern police force of this day and age. To be fair to the Minister, he has inherited a legacy left by his predecessors. If there was dissatisfaction and a near revolt in the Garda Síochána some months ago it was due to the fact that some of the Minister's predecessors were unaware of the changing times and the changing needs of the Garda force. I should like to join other Senators tonight in paying him a tribute because he has taken a step in the right direction. I, too, should like to voice the view that the Minister should consider at the earliest practicable date increasing the number beyond the 400 plus 600, that is, 1,000 extra men which he visualises in the coming months. However, he may have practical difficulties in that regard. Facilities may not be there to train the men. Obviously it is no good suggesting increasing the force by another 1,000 men unless we have the necessary facilities. Perhaps the Minister would give some indication of what facilities are available, what number of men can be trained at present, what it would require to provide extra facilities and how soon these facilities can be provided.

The basic requirements for a first-class Garda force is, first, a high standard of morale. That is something that was very much under pressure in the past year or so. The Minister has taken a step in the right direction in improving the morale of the force. Secondly— something that is often forgotten—is the co-operation of the public. It is sad to read, as we do from time to time, of cases where one garda or two gardaí are endeavouring to apprehend some men for trying to break into a premises, or being mixed up in some criminal offence, while the crowd stand by doing nothing or else interfere with the gardaí in the course of their duty. If we, the people, wish to have an effective Garda force we have to play our part in making it possible for the gardaí to be effective. No two, three, four or half a dozen gardaí can hope to carry out their duties under difficult circumstances unless they have at least the moral support of whatever people may be in the vicinity. They certainly cannot do their duty if they have the active opposition of even a section of a large crowd. They must also have the support of the judiciary in dealing fairly but firmly with criminals, particularly criminals well known to them and to the public. Lastly, something which has been touched on here but is worth repeating, the Garda force must be free from political influence or political pressures of any description. They must not alone be free from it but be seen to be free from it. Like the Army the Garda force should be an attractive and rewarding career for a young man in the 18 to 27 age group. He should feel he is going into a force which offers him a future, gives him not alone reasonable material rewards but also a feeling that he is doing something for his country, that he is an important unit in our society, and that in time he will get reasonable opportunities for advancement. He must obviously have good conditions materially, a modern, well-equipped barracks with the latest facilities for the detection and suppression of crime.

MainHeading.P: Again, I should like to draw the Minister's attention—it has been done on a number of occasions both in the Dáil and in the Limerick City Council —to the deplorable condition of the main barracks in Limerick city, William Street barracks. I know the Minister has acquired a new and very suitable site in Limerick city and I hope that he will not allow the present year to pass without the commencement of the building of the new barracks. The present 200-year-old rabbit warren has long outlived its usefulness, and if the Minister wants to preserve a contented Garda force in Limerick it is vital that he goes ahead without further delay with the building of a modern barracks in his native city. There is a crying need in the north side of the city of Limerick for a new Garda barracks. Again the Minister has promised to provide this facility but to date there is no sign of such a barracks.

The criminal of today, as other Senators have observed, is a very sophisticated individual. In many instances he is a daring, ruthless professional, who knows what he wants and where to get it quickly and quietly. If the Garda force has to deal with such individuals they must, obviously, be adequate in strength and fully equipped for what can be a very dangerous task. I do not pretend to be an expert on the organisation of the Garda force but it strikes me that the duties, as another Senator mentioned, that devolve on a garda are in fact para-military duties. We have to decide if we want the Garda to carry out such duties. If they are to carry them out they should be properly equipped, in numbers and in modern facilities, to carry them out. If they are not to carry out those duties the Army will have to do them. We cannot leave the Garda force in the position of being called out in an emergency to deal with a riot or near riot and afterwards criticise them because they are unable to cope with the situation because of a lack of numbers or a lack of proper equipment. It is most important that the Minister and his advisers should decide as soon as possible what kind of force is required and organise it accordingly. References have been made to the duties of Garda in the cities and rural areas.

Speaker.P: Perhaps I may intervene to indicate that it is now past the normal time for adjournment.
I think it was agreed to go on for a short period.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. E. Ryan Mr. E. Ryan
Speaker.P: As the Senator is the last speaker and, as I understand, the Minister will not be more than ten minutes in replying, I suggest we should continue.
Does any other Senator wish to speak?

I shall not be more than a few minutes. It is quite true that we have nowadays the political or pseudo-political criminals, the individuals who take advantage of a period of political tension or emotional feeling to rob and plunder and even endanger the lives of citizens who stand in their way. We are all conversant with instances that have taken place recently, such as robbing of banks, breaking into properties, endangering places of employment, attacks on unarmed security forces. They are the type of activities I am alluding to. If the Garda have to undertake those duties in difficult conditions, in periods of high tension in the country, they will have to be properly equipped to do so. Again it raises the question of what type of force we want. If they are to undertake dangerous and difficult duties they will have to be provided with the proper equipment.

MainHeading.P: I wonder if the present centralisation of the force is the best possible way. I notice that the organisation provides for one commissioner, two deputy commissioners and two assistant commissioners. I wonder if the organisation should not be on a more regional basis with a deputy commissioner or an assistant commissioner in charge of a wide area, something on the style of army organisation in which you have the Southern Command, Western Command and so on. That may not be practical in regard to a civil force such as the Garda but we are living in very unusual times. I cannot see the times changing in the foreseeable future. Now that we have a young and active Minister for Justice I believe we should prepare ourselves for the continuance of present conditions for some time to come. We should not expect too much from our Garda force without giving them the opportunity of dealing with those situations.

I was very pleased to read in the Dáil Official Report that the Minister is encouraging the restoration of the Garda Band. He mentioned that he hopes to have it reconstituted in time for the celebrations to mark the 50th anniversary of the founding of the force. It would be a very suitable way of marking the 50th anniversary and I hope the Minister will be successful in his efforts.

I should also like to pay tribute to the Garda boxing team which brought honour to the force in the past. I am sure other Senators will remember the Garda boxing team, a number of whom won international honours for this country. It is a pity that they have been disbanded. I think athletics, rowing, boxing and football, should be part and parcel of a force that offers to a young man a worthwhile career. I hope the Minister will take this matter into consideration also. Material rewards are obviously important but there are other intangible things that go with it, such as pride in membership of the Garda force and the opportunities to excel and take part in athletics. All those matters go hand in hand in having a contented force. Above all else, I think a garda would like to feel that he has the goodwill and support of the public he serves and has served so well over the past half century.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. O'Malley) Desmond J. O'Malley
Speaker.P: I should like to thank Senators on all sides for the welcome they have given to the Bill. I appreciate the suggestions they have put forward for the improvement of the force which will be borne in mind and fully examined.

MainHeading.P: A point that was made by many Senators related to the closing of rural Garda stations. Because of the number of Senators who mentioned the point I should like to refer to it first. There seems to be an impression still abroad that Garda stations are in the process of being closed, that closures have recently taken place and that more closures are imminent. This is not so. Since May, 1970, the only Garda stations which have been closed are those for which arrangements to close were made in advance of May, 1970, and could not be changed when I became Minister. Since then none have been closed and I have no proposals at present to close further stations.

I can see the value of a system of centralisation on the lines recommended by Senator West. He recommended the closing of rural stations and the concentration of gardaí in central areas. In a country such as this that policy can be brought so far and I think we have brought it far enough by now. That has been my view over the past 18 months or so. Except in a few isolated cases I do not think it would be wise to close any more stations and I have no present proposals in that respect. I want to make that very clear, because many people seem to be under the misapprehension that stations have closed or are about to close. That is not so. The facts are, as I have given them to the House, that only about two stations throughout the country have been closed since May, 1970.

With regard to the implementation of the recommendations in the Conroy Report, I should like to make it very clear that there are only five of the 52 recommendations which have not yet been dealt with. Senators have made the suggestion that a great deal remains to be done in that regard. That is not so. I shall not go into the full details of how many of them have been fully implemented, and so on. In the Dáil Official Report, at column 1338, of volume 258, on the Second Stage of this Bill in the Dáil, it sets out everything in detail, and for that reason I shall not repeat it now.

Senator O'Higgins made a point about a large number of gardaí resigning voluntarily at the present time, and that this indicates a poor morale. I want to give the figures to the House to indicate that the very contrary is the case. In the year 1969, which would have been the pre-Conroy year—it was the year in which the Conroy Commission was sitting—there were 82 voluntary resignations of all ranks from the force. In 1971, the figure was 33—a reduction of well over 50 per cent. The fact that only 33 men voluntarily resigned out of a force of 6,560 is an indication of how attractive, in fact, conditions in the force are, and is at variance with any suggestion that there is an undue proportion of resignations. I would safely say that 33 out of 6,600 must be considerably less than 1 per cent, and must probably be the smallest of any State service, or of any similar organisation of that size. The proportion of civil servants or of soldiers who resign voluntarily would be far above that. In addition to the small number of people who are now resigning voluntarily, we have been strongly pressed in the last year by people who resigned voluntarily over the past two, three or four years to take them back. It is one of my unpleasant problems to have to resist that. It has never been the Commissioner's policy to take them back and I do not wish to interfere with it. I mention this simply as an indication of the anxiety of those who did resign over the past few years to be taken back at the moment.

I am glad to be able to tell the House that the current recruiting drive seems, so far as one can judge—it is not yet completed; Friday next is the closing date—to be remarkably successful. Reports from various parts of the country are that there is a big number of applicants. It appears that we shall be able to fill all our vacancies.

A number of Senators have suggested that, even though 1,000 is a big number, we really need more. I am not certain that I could accept that at all, particularly when we have not seen how the 1,000 are going to work out. Senators who made that suggestion perhaps do not consider all the possible implications. One of them is —I think it was touched on by Senator Russell—that when you are recruiting men to a permanent force, men who will be 30, 40 or 45 years in the force, it is very bad to take in an enormous number one particular year, because there is a limit to the talent that is around in 1972. The 1973 class, as it were, and the 1971 group should get a crack at the whip too.

There will be a limited number of very good people this year. If you overextend yourself completely, you will get many people who might not be of the calibre that we really want. That is one of the reasons why I extended the age limit a bit on both ends, in order to try and widen the field of selection, so that we can take the best that can be found. There is also the factor that with Templemore carrying 1,000 extra now, between last year and this year, it is at its absolute maximum. This is stretching it to the limit and that is all that can be taken.

Senator Belton inquired how, if we are taking 1,000, only 800 jobs are advertised. The reply to that is that we have already got in 200 of them— 200 came in last year and an extra 800 this year. In addition to that, we will be recruiting an extra 140 or 150 to cover natural wastage, such as retirement, resignations, deaths and so on. This means that in the financial year 1972-1973 about 940 or 950 recruits will have to be found, which puts our resources to the complete limit. Even if it did not, it is the optimum number that we should seek to bring in in any one year because our quality of intake will suffer if we go beyond that.

Senator Keery and other Senators made reference to the place of the policeman in the community, and it is a very valid point. I have often felt that, for one reason or another, the policeman is not as cherished in our community as he might be. Unfortunately, it has been a trait in the Irish character not to give the assistance to one's own police force that should be expected from a good citizen.

The police forces of other countries tend to get assistance more readily than happens here. We have seen unpleasant aspects of this in recent years —some of which, I think, Senator Russell referred to—where gardaí are grappling with an offender whom they have apprehended in the course of some crime, and not alone do they not get assistance from members of the public, but I regret very much to say that often they are impeded by members of the public who seek to assist the criminal. This kind of thing very often ends up in injury to the garda involved. This is deplorable and it is a tendency we should try to do everything we can to stamp out at the earliest possible moment. In order to establish and strengthen the position of the policeman in the community, particularly in regard to getting into contact with young people and possible potential offenders, what I hope to see, now that we will be recruiting extra men, is some sort of extension of our present juvenile liaison scheme—it is rather limited at the moment because of numbers—in conjunction with the Department's welfare service.

Speaker.P: It is an excellent scheme.

It is. An extension of it which might be good was suggested in the Dáil by Deputy Moore and by Deputy Dr. O'Connell: that is, attaching a garda full-time to a community centre in a large urban area, if we could do this. This would assist greatly in improving the relationship between ordinary members of the public and possible potential offenders and the Garda.

At the moment, unfortunately, there is a certain element in the community who tend to look on the Garda only as people they come up against when they are in some trouble. They look on the Garda, therefore, in a negative rather than in a positive way. The contribution which the Garda Síochána, as well as any police force, can make to a community is a very positive one. It is not just physical prevention all the time. If we have enough men now to start working on these lines it can change, not overnight but over a reasonable period, much of what is wrong in the fundamental attitude of some people to the police in this country.

MainHeading.P: I might mention, in conjunction with that point, that I am conscious of the necessity to try to project the image of the police here as well as possible. With that in mind I have appointed recently a PRO for the Garda who has just commenced his duties. I hope to extend that aspect of it to enable the Garda to communicate better, as it were, with the community and thereby obtain the assistance from and support of the community which they need so badly.

One of the consequences of the implementation of the recommendations of the Conroy Report has given rise to some difficulties, as Senator West mentioned, that is, the question of overtime. It was recommended by Conroy but the implementation was not considered by that commission except in a very general way. Unfortunately, they did not—I suppose one could not reasonably have expected them to—consider the detailed working out of how it was to be implemented. It is understandable, because of pressures at the time, that it was implemented very quickly. It has had many teething troubles and has taken from 18 months to two years to get it sorted out. The precise form in which Conroy recommended it was not necessarily the best. There are discussions going on at the moment about amending the system. It caused trouble in the first 12 months or so while getting used to it and there were complaints about delay in payment and so on. At present there are no delays in the Department in payment and there have been no complaints in this respect over the past few months.

Senator O'Higgins referred to the unfortunate affair of the British Embassy and made the point that there were insufficient gardaí there at the time. I dealt in depth with that incident at column 1013 of volume 258 of the Dáil debate on Northern Ireland on 4th February. I will not go into it in any great detail now but I should like to say that I discussed that matter in great detail with the Commissioner before, during and after the incident. He was satisfied that even if he had several hundred more men—he had many hundreds there but they were not all visible to the public; the back of the embassy had to be guarded from large crowds as well as the front, a point which is not known to many members of the public—he doubts if in the circumstances they could have met with any greater success.

He had several hundred more available to him at the time but in the exercise of his professional judgment he did not bring them in because one of the most fatal errors you could make would be to commit all your resources to the one spot when they might be needed elsewhere. In this matter I hope he will not take it amiss if I say to Senator O'Higgins and the people who make suggestions about matters such as this that both he and I are amateurs. I have found from experience that it is right not to seek to interfere with the professional judgment of the man whose profession it is to assess these matters. If I had not been involved, I might look at a television set and say “It is a pity the Garda did not do this or that”. The Garda are really the best judges of that themselves.

Speaker.P: I accept that fully.

I do not want to sound critical of Senator O'Higgins. In that sense I am as much an amateur about it as he is. I might avail myself of this opportunity in this House to repeat what I said in the other House with regard to the conduct of the gardaí on that occasion. It was splendid and showed the highest degree of courage in the face of a very difficult situation. One of the aspects of it that impressed me was their refusal to wear protective garments or to use implements of a certain type which they felt might aggravate the situation or cause greater damage in the long run. They did that at personal risk to themselves. The unfortunate fact is that 34 of them were injured to one degree or another, fortunately, none of them seriously but several of them quite painfully injured and detained in hospital.

It is interesting to note that when later that night, in order to clear a much smaller crowd that had gathered in another part of Merrion Square and had thrown petrol bombs at various buildings, including the National Maternity Hospital in Holles Street which was struck by a petrol bomb thrown deliberately by this particular mob, the gardaí drew their batons and charged that mob. One newspaper, the following morning carried a fairly detailed description of what was described as Garda brutality. Apparently a couple of thugs had received cut heads as a result of the baton charge. The fact that 34 members of the Garda were taken to hospital as a result of the events of that day left the same newspaper unmoved which is a bad reflection on our society.

I think I have covered most of the points which have been raised. I do not wish, because of the lateness of the hour, to detain the House any longer. I thank Senators for their reception of the Bill and ask them to give it a Second Reading.
Question put and agreed to.
Agreed to take remaining Stages today.
Bill put through Committee, reported without amendment, received for final consideration and passed.
The Seanad adjourned at 10.30 p.m. until 10.30 a.m. on Thursday, 24th February, 1972.
